236.01 DUTIES OF DIRECTOR.
   The Department of Finance shall be under the direction of the Director of
Finance who shall perform duties as set forth in these Codified Ordinances, as
directed by the City Manager and as follows:
   (a)   Keep in proper books a full and accurate record of all moneys received
and disbursed on behalf of the City and of all moneys due to and from the City
upon contracts and orders upon which the City is obligated and otherwise;
   (b)   Receive and have custody of all moneys paid to the City and disburse
all City moneys in accordance with the City Charter and ordinances, signing all
drafts upon the City Treasury in making such disbursements;
   (c)   Render a monthly report to the City Manager reflecting the financial
condition of the City, showing monthly receipts, encumbrances and outstanding
balances of all funds;
   (d)   Certify that funds are available according to law to pay moneys
provided by all con tracts, agreements or other obligations for the expenditure
of City funds; no such contract, agreement or other obligation shall be valid
until so certified;
   (e)   Make payment of the interest and principal on the bonded debt when due
and keep accurate records of such debt and of such payments thereon;
   (f)   Prepare the City payrolls;
   (g)   Administer all employee pension and benefit funds, receiving such
funds, acting as custodian thereof and making disbursements therefrom, signing
drafts and checks for such purposes, according to law;
   (h)   Enter into contracts with legal depositories for the deposit of all
funds of the City with such depositories, rent safety deposit boxes or
otherwise provide for the safekeeping of securities and other documents for
payment of money to the City and maintain custody of all documents evidencing
investments of the City and of pension and benefit funds of City employees;
   (i)   Prepare and submit such reports as may be required by law; and
   (j)   Assist the City Manager in the preparation of the annual budget.
(Ord. 71-27. Passed 6-8-71.)
236.02 OBLIGATIONS, CONTRACTS AND PURCHASE ORDERS.
   Every undertaking by the City involving the expenditure of City money shall,
if appropriate, be in writing, and if such expenditure is for the purchase of
services or materials, it shall be in the form of a purchase order or a
contract.
   Except as otherwise set forth herein, and excepting obligations for
professional services and utilities, including, but not limited to, phone,
electric and gas, the Director of Finance and/or the City Manager shall attach
to each obligation a certificate signed by him or her that the estimated amount
of money required to meet the obligation of the City has been lawfully
appropriated and is in the City Treasury or is in the process of collection to
the credit of the fund involved, free from any prior encumbrance. In the case
of a contract to continue beyond any current year and to involve expenditures
of money in future years, the Director and/or the City Manager need only
certify as to the money estimated to be paid by the City thereunder during the
current year.
(Ord. 83-13. Passed 4-26-83; Ord. 94-13. Passed 6-14-94.)
236.03 PAYMENT OF FUNDS.
   The Director of Finance shall require an invoice to be submitted to him or
her, with written certification thereon by the head of the department or
division of the City concerned, to the effect that the goods, services or other
obligations for which the invoice is rendered have been delivered or performed
in the manner, quantity and quality specified, or have been otherwise
authorized prior to the issuance of the City's draft in payment thereof,
whereupon the draft shall be promptly issued in payment.
(Ord. 83-13. Passed 4-26-83.)
236.04 PAYROLLS.
   Payrolls shall be submitted to the City Manager for approval, when prepared
by the Director of Finance, and, upon the Manager's approval thereof, the
Director shall issue drafts in payment thereof when due. It shall not be
necessary for the Director to encumber in advance or to certify as to the
availability of funds appropriated for personal services, except those obtained
on a contractual basis, provided that upon issuance of such warrants the
Director shall immediately cause the appropriate funds to be encumbered to the
extent of the drafts issued.
(Ord. 71-27. Passed 6-8-71.)
236.05 PAYMENTS ON CONTRACTS.
   Prior to the making of partial or final payments on contracts, the City
Manager shall certify that the contract for which payment is to be made has
been complied with. In the case of partial payments, such payments shall be
made on estimates of the amount and value of the work accomplished and/or
material furnished; the certificates or estimates shall show the amount and
value of all the work accomplished and/or material furnished and the amount of
money paid on previous estimates or certificates. Only the difference in value
between the latest estimate and amounts paid on previous estimates, less any
money retained as guarantees or for other valid reasons, shall be paid as a
partial payment, except in the case of a final payment. Upon receiving such
certificates, estimates or invoices, properly certified, the Director of
Finance shall then issue drafts in payments.
(Ord. 71-27. Passed 6-8-71.)
236.06 DIRECTOR AS AUDITOR.
   (a)   The Director of Finance is designated as Auditor of the City and is
authorized to do all things required of an auditor of a city under the
Constitution and laws of the State not inconsistent with the City Charter.
(Ord. 71-27. Passed 6-8-71.)
   (b)   The Director, as Auditor, may cause a seal to be created for his or
her use.
(Ord. 71-25. Passed 4-13-71.)
236.07 INVESTMENT AND DEPOSITORY POLICY.
   (a)   Policy Statement. It is the policy of the City to deposit and invest
public funds in a manner which will provide the maximum security with the
highest investment return while meeting the daily cash flow demands of the City
and conforming to all applicable local statutes governing the investment of
public funds.
   (b)   Scope.
      (1)   This section applies to all moneys of the City, except for moneys
whose investment and deposit are otherwise controlled by an independent board,
advisory council or trustee under requirements of bond indentures or endowment
trusts (as in the case of certain bond debt service funds, certain debt service
reserve funds and certain nonexpendable trust funds). The City funds subject to
this section are hereinafter referred to as the “active portfolio.”
      (2)   Cash balances from the several different funds of the City may be
pooled for investment purposes. Unless otherwise restricted, all interest
earnings will be credited to the General Fund of the City.
   (c)   Objectives. The following investment and deposit objectives will be
applied in the management of City funds:
      (1)   The primary objective of the City's investment activities is the
preservation of capital and the protection of investment principal.
      (2)   All investment and deposit transactions must be in conformance with
all applicable laws and ordinances prevailing at the time of the transaction.
      (3)   The City's investment portfolio will remain sufficiently liquid to
enable the City to meet operating requirements which might be reasonably
anticipated.
      (4)   In investing public funds, the City will strive to maximize the
return on the portfolio, but will avoid assuming unreasonable investment risks.
      (5)   The City will diversify its investments to avoid incurring
unreasonable and avoidable risks regarding specific security types or
individual financial institutions.
      (6)   Banks vary in the services they provide, their service fees,
interest rates on interim investments and the minimum compensating balances
required for demand-deposit accounts. The City's objective is to obtain good
banking services while minimizing the cost of such services to the City.
   (d)   Prudent Person Standard; Liability.
      (1)   The deposit and investment of City funds shall be made with the
exercise of that degree of judgment and care, under circumstances then
prevailing, which persons of prudence, discretion and intelligence exercise in
the management of their own affairs, not for speculation but for investment,
considering the probable safety of their capital as well as the probable income
to be derived (hereinafter referred to as “the prudent person standard”).
      (2)   The standard of prudence to be used by City officials involved in
the deposit and investment of City funds shall be the prudent person standard
and shall be applied in the context of managing an overall portfolio. City
officials acting in accordance with written procedures and this section, and
exercising due diligence, shall be relieved of personal responsibility for an
individual security's credit risk or market price changes, provided that
deviations from expectations are reported in a timely fashion and appropriate
action is taken to control adverse developments.
   (e)   Delegation of Authority; Engaging in Investment Transactions.
      (1)   Authority to manage the City's deposits and investment program is
derived from the City Charter. The City Manager and the Director of Finance, as
Chief Financial Officer of the City, shall be charged with the administration
of this section. The City Manager and the Director of Finance shall have the
right to assign such duties and responsibilities as he or she deems appropriate
in keeping with the efficient and prudent management of this section. Such
assignment shall include explicit delegation of authority to persons
responsible for investment transactions.
      (2)   No person may engage in an investment transaction, except as
provided under the terms of this section and the procedures adopted by the
Treasury Investment Board.
   (f)   Conflicts of Interest: Disclosure of Financial Interests by Officers
and Employees.
      (1)   Officers and employees involved in the deposit and investment
process shall refrain from personal business activity which could conflict
with, or have the appearance of a conflict with, the proper execution of the
investment program or which could impair their ability to make impartial
investment decisions.
      (2)   Officers and employees involved in the deposit and investment of
City funds shall disclose to the City's independent auditors any material
financial interests in financial institutions that conduct business with the
City and, further, disclose any large personal financial/investment positions
that could be related to the performance of the City's portfolio.
      (3)   Officers and employees involved in the investment of City funds
shall subordinate their personal investment transactions to those of the City,
particularly with regard to the time of purchases and sales.
   (g)   Internal Controls; Review. The Director of Finance shall have
established a system of controls to regulate the activities of subordinate
officials. Such internal controls and compliance therewith shall be subject to
review during the annual audit conducted by or on behalf of the Auditor of the
State of Ohio.
   (h)   Maturity of Investments.
      (1)   To the extent possible, the City will attempt to match the term of
maturity of its investments with anticipated cash flow requirements. Unless
matched to a specific cash flow requirement, the City will not directly invest
in securities maturing more than ten years from the month of settlement. A
security trading on a “when issued” basis may be purchased or sold if all
aspects of the security and the trade meet the requirements of this section and
the settlement date is no longer than thirty days after the trade date.
      (2)   As an alternative, for securities which repay principal prior to
maturity, such as certain mortgage backed securities, the City will not
directly invest in securities with an expected average life of more than ten
years. Expected average lives must be substantiated by forecasts independent of
the City and the dealer from which the security is purchased, such as the
Bloomberg System.
   (i)   Authorized Financial Institutions; Broker/Dealers.
      (1)   Depositories.
         A.   Each of the following criteria shall be met in order for a bank
to be considered an eligible depository:
            1.   The bank shall be a nationally chartered commercial bank
organized under the laws of the State of Ohio.
            2.   The bank shall be doing business in, and situated or operating
a full-service branch office within the boundaries of, the City of Englewood.
            3.   The bank shall have exhibited consistent creditworthiness, as
evidenced by at least an “average” rating within its peer group in the three
most recent issues of an industry-recognized bank rating publishing service,
such as IDC Financial Publishing's Bank Financial Quarterly, Sheshunoff s Bank
Quarterly or a similar rating service selected by the Director of Finance,
which utilizes measures of capital risk, asset quality, margin, earnings and
leverage (CAMEL) to determine the relative strength of financial institutions.
The term “average” shall be defined by the Director of Finance in the absence
of an explicit definition by the rating service.
         B.   To the extent practical, the Director of Finance will minimize
the number of depositories for the efficient, effective and economical deposit
of City funds, and may do so by issuing a formal request for proposal as
frequently as he or she determines necessary. Exceptions to this centralization
of depositories provision will be made when trust agreements or other legal
mandates dictate specific handling or investment requirements that may not be
obtained or most efficiently managed through existing depositories.
         C.   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized to enter into the
depository agreements set forth in subsection (n) hereof.
         D.   All City funds deposited with depository banks shall be secured
by collateral as prescribed in subsection (n) hereof.
      (2)   Broker/dealers.
         A.   Eligibility requirements.
            1.   Securities shall be purchased only through:
               a.   Nationally chartered commercial banks, organized within and
under laws of one of the United States, which are insured through the Federal
Deposit Insurance Corporation and which are members of the Federal Reserve;
               b.   Broker/dealer firms which are registered with the Financial
Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) and which are licensed to sell securities
within the State of Ohio; or
               c.   Primary securities dealers, as designated by the Federal
Reserve Bank of New York and which qualify under Securities and Exchange
Commission Uniform Net Capital Rule 15c3-l.
            2.   The minimum acceptable criteria to be met in order to be
approved as an authorized broker/dealer will include:
               a.   The broker/dealer must meet the eligibility requirements
set forth in paragraph (i)(2)A.1. hereof; and
               b.   The broker/dealer and the personnel assigned to service the
City's account must be licensed to sell securities in the State of Ohio.
         B.   Authority of Director of Finance regarding eligibility of broker/
dealers. The Director of Finance shall:
            1.   Make additions to the authorized list when the above-described
criteria are met.
            2.   Make deletions from the list as directed:
               a.   If and as directed by ordinance of the City Council;
               b.   Upon failure of a broker/dealer to meet the foregoing
investment and deposit policy requirements; or
               c.   Upon request of a broker/dealer.
            3.   Make deletions from the list of his or her discretion, based
on the following criteria or circumstances:
               a.   Perceived financial difficulties of a broker/dealer;
               b.   Consistent lack of competitiveness by a broker/dealer;
               c.   Lack of experience or familiarity of the account
representative in providing service to large institutional accounts; or
               d.   When deemed in the best interest of the City.
   (j)   Authorized Investments.
      (1)   The City Manager and the Director of Finance may invest on behalf
of and in the name of the City in only those instruments which appear on the
List of Authorized Investment Instruments (Exhibit A, attached to original
Ordinance 96-13, passed March 27, 1996, as updated) and only at a price not
exceeding their fair market value. The List of Authorized Investment
Instruments will be updated by the Director of Finance as necessary and will be
kept on file in the office of the City Auditor.
      (2)   Securities eligible for inclusion on the List of Authorized
Investment Instruments include:
         A.   Bonds, notes or other obligations of or guaranteed by the United
States, or those for which the faith of the United States is pledged for the
payment of principal and interest thereon;
         B.   Bonds, notes, debentures or any other obligations or securities
issued by any Federal Government agency, instrumentality, or Government
Sponsored Enterprise;
         C.   Deposits in eligible financial institutions;
         D.   Bankers' acceptances issued by banks ranked within the top 100
banks, based upon asset size, or issued by banks within the State of Ohio with
at least two billion dollars ($2,000,000,000) in assets;
         E.   Commercial paper which, when purchased, is rated at least P-1 by
Moody's Investor Services and A-1 by Standard and Poor's, and corporate notes
and other debt which, when purchased, is rated AA or better by Moody's Investor
Services and/or Standard and Poor's;
         F.   Bonds, notes or other obligations of the State of Ohio and its
political subdivisions;
         G.   The State Treasury Asset Reserve of Ohio (STAR Ohio);
         H.   No-load money market mutual funds consisting exclusively of
obligations described in paragraphs (j)(2)A. and B. hereof; and
         I.   Repurchase agreements with institutions which have executed a
master repurchase agreement, entered into between the City and that particular
institution. Each master repurchase agreement will provide for:
            1.   Collateralization of each repurchase agreement consisting
exclusively of obligations described in paragraphs (j)(2)A. and B. hereof, the
market value of which shall not be less than 102 percent of the principal
amount of each repurchase agreement plus accrued interest;
            2.   Safekeeping of the collateral by the City's third-party
safekeeping agent; and
            3.   Settlement of each repurchase agreement on a delivery-versus-
payment basis. Master repurchase agreements may provide for substitution of
collateral by the broker/dealer with the agreement of the City.
      (3)   Securities which are specifically prohibited for investment include
interest-only, mortgage-backed securities or other securities for which there
exists a hypothetical mathematical possibility of a negative yield, excluding
default risk, if the security is held to maturity.
   (k)   Diversification.
      (1)   To avoid incurring unreasonable risks inherent in over-investing in
specific instruments, individual financial institutions or maturities, the
Director of Finance will diversify the active portfolio as follows:
Instrument Type Maximum Percent of Active Maximum Percent of Portfolio by
                Portfolio                 Obligor
Instrument Type             Maximum Percent of Active Maximum Percent of
                            Portfolio                 Portfolio by Obligor
U.S. Treasury obligations   100                       100
Authorized U.S. Federal
agency securities and U.S.
Government- sponsored       100                       100
corporations and
instrumentalities
Nonnegotiable certificates  100                       25
of deposit
State of Ohio Treasurer's   100                       100
Investment Pool (STAR Ohio)
Prime commercial paper      25                        10
Commercial debt - demand    50                        50
notes
Commercial debt - notes and 25                        10
bonds
Bankers' acceptances        25                        10
 
      (2)   No transaction needs to be executed when, through inadvertence or
unusual circumstances, a maturity in the active portfolio causes the percentage
of a type or category of investment to exceed the diversification limits set
forth above. Any transaction executed after such infraction shall work toward
returning the active portfolio to compliance with such limits.
      (3)   The City Manager and/or the Finance Director may set lower limits
on the amount of funds which can be placed in any investment category.
   (l)   Competitive Bidding.
      (1)   The purpose of competitive bidding is to strengthen the investment
program in terms of level and consistency of performance. When purchasing
securities, the Director of Finance will obtain the minimum number of offerings
as follows:
 
Minimum Acceptable Type of Security   Number of Offerings
Government securities                 2
Nonnegotiable certificates of deposit 3
Bankers' acceptances                  2
Commercial paper                      3
 
      (2)   When selling any type of security, the Director of Finance will use
his or her best efforts to obtain a minimum of three bids.
      (3)   The right is reserved to reject the offering or bid yielding the
highest return if such offering or bid is inconsistent with the City's
investment strategy, i.e. maturity, risk, diversification, liquidity, etc.
      (4)   Price and rate quotations on all trades shall be obtained from
authorized financial institutions and dealers within and outside the City. In
the case of a purchase or sale of securities where all other factors are
considered by the Director of Finance to be equal, placement will be made in
favor of the institution situated within the City if two or more offerings or
bids are the same.
   (m)    Safekeeping and Custody. In order to minimize default-risk, the
Director of Finance will require the delivery of investment instruments as
follows:
      (1)   Government securities, bankers' acceptances, commercial paper and
other authorized money market securities.
         A.   All authorized investment securities shall be settled in a
delivery-versus-payment method. Book entry or physical securities shall be
safekept by a third-party safekeeping agent, in the agent's Federal Reserve
customer account, correspondent money center bank customer custody account or
Depository Trust Corporation (DTC) customer custody account.
         B.   Each delivery and safekeeping shall be evidenced by a safekeeping
receipt.
      (2)   Nonnegotiable interest-bearing time certificates of deposit.
         A.   The City will take possession, for safekeeping in its own vaults,
of all certificates of deposit or document(s) evidencing a certificate of
deposit in accordance with Ohio R.C. 135.14, the acceptable time of delivery
being no later than 2:00 p.m. on the day of settlement.
         B.   In the event that the certificate of deposit or document(s)
evidencing the certificate of deposit must be prepared at a home office of the
issuing bank outside the City, the City will require an overnight safekeeping
document and delivery of the certificate of deposit or document(s) evidencing a
certificate of deposit no later than 12:00 noon on the first business day after
the date of settlement.
      (3)   Repurchase agreements. (See subsection (j) hereof.)
   (n)   Collateralization of City Deposits.
      (1)   With the approval of the Director of Finance, a depository may
provide collateral for deposits of the City with a single pool of securities
pledged toward all deposits of public funds held by the depository, in the
manner provided in Ohio R.C. 135.181.
      (2)   Unless secured in the manner provided in Ohio R.C. 135.181, all
deposits of the City shall be secured by pledged collateral in the manner
provided in Ohio R.C. 135.18.
      (3)   The method of collateralization of City deposits shall be set forth
in a depository agreement between the City and the depository institution. The
depository agreement, in accordance with requirements set forth by the Federal
Depository Insurance Corporation, shall be:
         A.   In writing;
         B.   Executed by the depository institution and any person claiming as
adverse interest thereunder, including the obligor, contemporaneously with the
acquisition of the asset by the depository institution;
         C.   Approved by the board of directors of the depository institution
or its loan committee, which approval shall be reflected in the minutes of said
board or committee, a copy of which is to be provided to the City for its
files;
         D.   Be continuously, from the date of its execution, an official
record of the depository institution; and
         E.   Approved by the City Law Department.
   (o)   Reporting. The Director of Finance will be responsible for providing
regular semi-annual reports to the City Council about the City's investment
activities. The report should include at least a summary of the City's
portfolio by institution and types of instruments, average maturity and changes
in portfolio size by fund.
   (p)   Modifications. Inasmuch that this section has been duly enacted by
ordinance of the City Council, any modification hereto shall be made only by
the appropriate legislative action of the City Council, except for those
periodic updates to the list of Authorized Investment Instruments appearing in
Exhibit A, attached to original Ordinance 96-13, passed March 27, 1996, as
required by subsection (j) hereof.
(Ord. 96-13. Passed 3-27-96; Ord. 08-10. Passed 10-14-08; Ord. 10-10. Passed 9-
28-10.)
236.08 TREASURY DEPOSITORIES. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: This section was repealed by Ordinance 84-17, passed
September 25, 1984.)
236.09 DEBT SERVICE INVESTMENT TRUST FUND. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: This section was repealed by Ordinance 19-15, passed
September 24, 2019.)
236.10 REQUESTS FOR TAX ADVANCES.
   The authority of the City to request, each fiscal year, an advance on moneys
in the County Treasury to the credit of the City is hereby vested in the City
Manager. In making the request for a given fiscal year, the City Manager shall
certify, in writing, to the County Auditor or his or her designated deputy that
this section remains in effect and that he or she requests, on behalf of the
City, that such advances be made. Once the City Manager has made the
certification and request under this section for a given fiscal year, the
Director of Finance is authorized during that fiscal year to request and to
receive for deposit to the proper fund such moneys as they accrue in the County
Treasury to the credit of the City. The requirement in general law that such
advances be requested by resolution adopted for each fiscal year is hereby
expressly superseded.
(Ord. 88-15. Passed 10-11-88.)
236.11 EXEMPTION FROM REQUIREMENTS OF OHIO R.C. CHAPTER 153.
   (a)   The Council hereby declares that the provisions of Ohio R.C. Chapter
153 pertaining to retainage requirements and construction escrow accounts are
deemed not applicable to the City.
   (b)   The Finance Director shall establish retainage regulations and
percentages for public improvement contracts which are in the best interest of
the City of Englewood and he or she is so empowered to prepare said regulations
and set said retainage percentages consistent with good business practices.
   (c)   Retained funds pursuant to any contract with the City shall be
maintained in accordance with regulations to be established by the Finance
Director, and he or she is so empowered to prepare said regulations consistent
with good business practices.
   (d)   Contractors are to be advised that preparation of proposals pursuant
to previous compliance with Ohio R.C. Chapter 153 are not a proper cost element
to be injected into any contracts with the City.
(Ord. 93-10. Passed 5-25-93.)
236.12 COLLECTION OF REVENUE BY CREDIT AND/OR DEBIT CARD TRANSACTIONS.
   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized to receive payments for City
services via credit and/or debit card transactions. Electronic revenue
transactions shall be subject to the same depository and financial reporting
requirements and controls as cash transactions.
(Ord. 08-2. Passed 2-12-08.)
236.13 LIABILITY FOR LOSS OF PUBLIC FUNDS.
   The Treasurer, or other officer of the municipality having the duties of a
treasurer or of a city auditor, shall not be held liable for a loss of public
funds when the officer has performed all official duties required of the
officer with reasonable care, but shall be liable only when a loss of public
funds results from the officer's negligence or other wrongful act.
(R.C. § 733.82)

238.01 QUALIFICATIONS OF DIRECTOR.
   The Director of the Department of Law shall be an attorney at law admitted
to practice in the courts of the State and the United States Courts for the
Southern District of Ohio.
(Ord. 71-39. Passed 8-10-71. )
238.02 DIRECTOR'S DUTIES GENERALLY.
   The Director of Law shall be accountable to the City Manager and to Council.
He or she shall perform the following duties:
   (a)   Attend all meetings of Council and of Council committees, boards and
commissions when requested;
   (b)   Advise and render opinions to Council, the City Manager, boards,
commissions and the administrative officers and departments on all matters of
law involving the City and to Council members, officers and departments in the
performance of their official duties, upon request in writing;
   (c)   Draft all ordinances, contracts, resolutions and other documents of a
legal nature to be made and entered into by the City and approve the form
thereof;
   (d)   Represent, or cause to be represented, the City or any department or
office thereof before all courts sitting within the State in actions at law or
in equity in which the City is a party;
   (e)   Assist in the preparation of documents and transcripts for the
issuance of bonds and notes of the City; and
   (f)   Perform such other duties as may be assigned to the office of Director
of Law by law and as may be necessary and proper in the administration of the
business of the City.
(Ord. 71-27. Passed 6-8-71; Ord. 71-39. Passed 8-10-71.)
238.03 BOND COUNSEL.
   Whenever Council proposes to issue bonds or notes to finance public
improvements, or for any other purpose authorized by the laws of the State, the
Director of Law may engage the services of any firm of recognized bond
attorneys to assist the Director in causing such bonds and notes to be issued
and to render approving opinions thereon to purchasers of such bonds and notes.
(Ord. 71-27. Passed 6-8-71.)
CHAPTER 240
Department of Police
   EDITOR'S NOTE: A Policy Manual and a Manual of Conduct and Discipline, Rules
and Regulations, both dated January 1, 1980, were adopted for the Department by
Resolution 29-80, passed February 12, 1980.
   The City enters into agreements from time to time with various neighboring
municipalities providing for the exchange of information and other needed
assistance between the police departments of such municipalities and the City.
Copies of the latest relevant legislation may be obtained, at cost, from the
Clerk of Council.
   The City executes labor agreements from time to time with recognized
representatives of members of the Department of Police, which agreements
provide for wages, benefits and conditions of employment for such members. The
provisions of this chapter and Chapter 252, therefore, apply only to those
members of the Department, and to those subjects, not otherwise provided for in
such agreements. Copies of the latest relevant legislation and of such
agreements may be obtained, at cost, from the Clerk of Council.

240.01 ESTABLISHMENT; COMPOSITION.
   There is hereby established a Police Department for the City, to be composed
of a Director of Police and such other officers and personnel as Council from
time to time determines.
(Ord. 75-18. Passed 3-25-75. )
240.02 GENERAL DUTIES.
   The Department of Police shall perform the following duties in providing
police services to the City:
   (a)   Be responsible for the preservation of the public peace and order, the
prevention and detection of crime, the apprehension of offenders of law, the
protection of persons and property and the enforcement of the criminal laws of
the United States, the State and the City; and
   (b)   Be responsible for making collections from all Municipal parking
meters and accounting therefor to the Director of Finance.
(Ord. 75-18. Passed 3-25-75. )
240.03 DUTIES OF DIRECTOR OF POLICE.
   The Director of Police shall be in charge of the Police Department and of
the personnel thereof. He or she shall be accountable to the City Manager and
shall perform the following duties:
   (a)   Formulate and recommend to the Manager, for approval, policies,
procedures, rules and regulations for the government and operation of the
Department and its personnel;
   (b)   Be responsible for the performance by the Department of the duties
assigned to it by Council, by State law, by these Codified Ordinances or by the
City Manager;
   (c)   Have control of the assignment of all personnel within the Department;
   (d)   Provide for the training and instruction of personnel within the
Department; and
   (e)   Perform such other duties as the City Manager may prescribe.
(Ord. 75-18. Passed 3-25-75. )
240.04 AUXILIARY POLICE OFFICERS.
   (a)   Establishment. There is hereby established the office of auxiliary
police officer of the City, which office may be filled, from time to time, with
as many persons in each capacity as the City Manager and the Director of Police
may find expedient.
   (b)   Appointment; Terms. The City Manager may, from time to time, appoint
deputy auxiliary police officers in such numbers, as above stated, to serve at
the pleasure of the City Manager. Such officers may be removed at any time from
office without a hearing and without cause being stated, upon notice from the
City Manager.
   (c)   Bond. Auxiliary police officers of the City shall post the same bond
as regular police officers of the City, the bond to be paid for by the
Municipality.
   (d)   Pension Fund; Rules and Regulations. Auxiliary police officers shall
not be entitled to share in the Police Relief and Pension Fund of the State as
they are not to be considered regular police officers and agents of the
Municipality.
   Rules and regulations not in conflict with this section may be promulgated
from time to time by the City Manager and the Director of Police, with the
advice of Council, and such rules and regulations shall be binding upon all
auxiliary police officers.
(Ord. 75-18. Passed 3-25-75.)
240.05 UNIFORM ALLOWANCE.
   Upon appointment, each police officer shall be furnished the basic police
uniform and equipment, which shall remain the property of the City. After one
year of service, each police officer shall be paid an annual uniform allowance
of three hundred seventy-five dollars ($375.00) in equal semiannual
installments.
(Ord. 89-11. Passed 2-28-89.)
240.06 EXTRATERRITORIAL JURISDICTION OF POLICE OFFICERS.
   (a)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 715.50, the power to exercise extraterritorial
jurisdiction by Municipal police officers to enforce the laws of the State and
the ordinances of the City, on land owned or leased by the City but lying
outside of the corporate limits, is hereby claimed.
   (b)   Municipal police officers shall enforce all criminal statutes of the
State on lands owned or leased by the City which lie outside of the corporate
limits.
   (c)   All ordinances of the City relative to criminal offenses and to police
regulations shall be enforced by police officers of the City on land owned by
the City but lying outside the corporate limits.
   (d)   Violations of such laws shall be prosecuted by Municipal police
officers in the Vandalia Municipal Court.
(Ord. 78-11. Passed 2-14-78. )
240.07 PROBATIONARY OFFICERS.
   (a)   Probationary police officers are officers during their first year of
service with the City.
   (b)   Probationary police officers shall be liable to reimburse the City for
the following expenses incurred by the City during their first year of service:
Basic training, recruiting, testing and selection expenses and equipment not
reusable within thirty days.
   (c)   When a probationary police officer leaves the service of the City, he
or she shall be liable to reimburse the City for a percentage of the expense of
the items of expense enumerated in subsection (b) hereof, as follows:
Month of Service   Percentage of Expense
First            .9583
Second            .8750

Eighth            .3750
Ninth            .2917
Tenth            .2083
Eleventh         .1250
Twelfth         .0833
(Ord. 80-23. Passed 5-13-80.)
240.08 EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE.
   (a)   In the event of an emergency and upon the request of the County
Sheriff's Office by the highest ranking officer of that office on duty at the
time of such emergency, the Department of Police is hereby authorized to
provide police assistance to the County Sheriff's Office upon the authorization
of the highest ranking officer of the Department on duty at the time that such
request is made.
   (b)   Police manpower and equipment may be recalled from such an emergency
at the sole discretion of the highest ranking officer of the Department on duty
at the time that such equipment and/or manpower is provided.
(Res. 32-81. Passed 4-14-81.)

242.01 ESTABLISHMENT; COMPOSITION; EMS DIVISION.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Department of Fire for the City, to be
composed of a Fire Chief and such other personnel as City Council from time to
time determines to be necessary.
   (b)   Emergency Medical Services (EMS) shall be a division of the Department
of Fire.
(Ord. 97-7. Passed 3-20-97.)
242.02 GENERAL DUTIES.
   The Department of Fire shall perform the following duties in providing fire
rescue services to the City:
   (a)   The Department of Fire shall be under the direction of the Fire Chief,
who shall be appointed by the City Manager and who shall perform duties as set
forth in these Codified Ordinances and as directed by the City Manager.
   (b)   The Fire Chief shall be responsible for the administration of the
Department of Fire and the Division of Emergency Medical Services and the
coordination of activities therein.
(Ord. 97-7. Passed 3-20-97.)
242.03 DUTIES OF THE FIRE CHIEF.
   The Fire Chief shall be in charge of the Department of Fire and of the
personnel thereof. He or she shall be accountable to the City Manager and shall
perform the following duties:
   (a)   Formulate and recommend to the City Manager, for approval, policies,
procedures, rules and regulations for the government and operation of the
Department and its personnel;
   (b)   Be responsible for the performance by the Department of the duties
assigned to it by City Council, by State law, by these Codified Ordinances and/
or by the City Manager;
   (c)   Have control of the assignment of all personnel within the Department;
   (d)   Provide for the training and instruction of personnel within the
Department; and
   (e)   Perform such other duties as the City Manager may prescribe.
(Ord. 97-7. Passed 3-20-97.)
242.04 VOLUNTEER PART-TIME FIRE FIGHTERS AND EMS PERSONNEL.
   (a)   Establishment. There is hereby established the office of volunteer
part-time fire fighter and EMS personnel for the City, which office may be
filled, from time to time, with as many persons in each capacity as the City
Manager and the Fire Chief may find expedient.
   (b)   Appointment; Terms.The City Manager may, from time to time, appoint
volunteer part-time fire fighters and EMS personnel in such numbers, as above
stated, to serve at the pleasure of the City Manger. Such officers may be
removed at any time from office without a hearing and without cause being
stated, upon notice from the City Manager.
   (c)   Bond. Volunteer part-time fire fighters and EMS personnel of the City
shall post the same bond as regular fire fighters of the City, the bond to be
paid for by the City.
   (d)   Pension Fund: Rules and Regulations. Volunteer part-time fire fighters
shall be entitled to share in the Fire Relief and Pension Fund of the State as
they are to be considered regular fire fighters of the City.
   Rules and regulations not in conflict with this section may be promulgated
from time to time by the City Manager and the Fire Chief, with the advice of
City Council, and such rules and regulations shall be binding upon all
volunteer part-time fire fighters and EMS personnel.
(Ord. 97-7. Passed 3-20-97.)
242.05 UNIFORM ALLOWANCE.
   Upon appointment, each full-time fire fighter shall be furnished the basic
uniform and equipment, which shall remain the property of the City. After one
year of service, each fire fighter shall be provided adequate uniforms as
determined by the Fire Chief.
(Ord. 97-7. Passed 3-20-97.)
242.06 EXTRATERRITORIAL JURISDICTION OF FIRE FIGHTERS.
   Pursuant to mutual aid agreements, the power to exercise extraterritorial
jurisdiction by City fire fighters and EMS personnel, on land owned or leased
by the City but lying outside of the corporate limits, is hereby claimed.
(Ord. 97-7. Passed 3-20-97.)
242.07 PROBATIONARY FIRE FIGHTERS.
   (a)   Probationary fire fighters are full-time personnel during their first
year of service with the City.
   (b)   Probationary fire fighters shall be liable to reimburse the City for
the following expenses incurred by the City during their first year of service:
Basic training, recruiting, testing and selection expenses and equipment not
reusable within thirty days.
   (c)   When a probationary fire fighter leaves the service of the City, he or
she shall be liable to reimburse the City for a percentage of the expense of
the items enumerated in subsection (b) hereof, as follows:
Month of Service   Percentage of Expenses
First            .9583
Second            .8750
Third            .7917
Fourth            .7083
Fifth            .6250
Sixth            .5417
Seventh         .4583
Eighth            .3750
Ninth            .2917
Tenth            .2083
Eleventh         .1250
Twelfth         .0833
(Ord. 97-7. Passed 3-20-97.)
242.08 EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE; MUTUAL AID.
   (a)   In the event of an emergency and upon the request of another fire
agency by an authorized officer of that office on duty at the time of such
emergency, the Department of Fire is hereby authorized to provide immediate
assistance upon the authorization of an authorized officer of the Department of
Fire on duty at the time that such request is made.
   (b)   Fire and EMS manpower and equipment may be recalled from such an
emergency at the sole discretion of the highest ranking officer of the
Department on duty at the time that such equipment and/or manpower is provided.
   (c)   The Fire Chief is hereby authorized to execute agreements on behalf of
the City for mutual aid. The terms and conditions of such an agreement shall be
left to the discretion of the Fire Chief and the City Manager.
(Ord. 97-7. Passed 3-20-97.)
242.09 CONTRACTS FOR FIRE AND EMS SERVICES.
   The City Manager is hereby authorized to negotiate contracts for fire and
EMS services, including the sharing of administration, personnel, equipment and
other items with neighboring political subdivisions.
(Ord. 97-7. Passed 3-20-97.)
242.10 PURCHASE OF ENGINES AND EQUIPMENT; FIRE ALARM TELEGRAPH LINES.
   The City Council may purchase the necessary fire engines and such other
equipment for the Department of Fire as are necessary for the extinguishment of
fires and the saving of lives, and may establish lines of fire alarm telegraph
within the Municipal limits of the City.
(Ord. 97-7. Passed 3-20-97.)
242.11 BUILDINGS.
   The City Council may provide or erect necessary and suitable buildings
containing rooms for fire engines and other equipment and for the meetings of
the fire and hose companies, within the Municipal limits of the City.
(Ord. 97-7. Passed 3-20-97.)
242.12 SCHOOLING OF OFFICERS AND FIRE FIGHTERS.
   The Fire Chief, upon prior authorization and approval by the City Manager,
may from time to time send any of the officers and fire fighters of the
Department of Fire to schools of instruction designed to promote the efficiency
of fire fighters and may pay their necessary expenses from the funds used for
the maintenance and operation of the Fire Department.
(Ord. 97-7. Passed 3-20-97.)
242.13 FIRE/EMS OPERATING FUND.
   (a)   A Fire/EMS Operating Fund is hereby established in and for the City.
   (b)   The purpose of the Fund shall be to provide for the expenses and
expenditures of the Fire Department and Emergency Medical Services.
(Ord. 97-10. Passed 5-13-97.)
242.14 CHARGES FOR EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES.
   (a)   The following fees and charges are hereby established to be charged
for emergency medical services provided by the Fire and Rescue Department.
      (1)   For residents and non-residents, Basic Life Support (BLS) and
Advanced Life Support Service (ALS) shall be charged at the most current rate
that would be the usual and customary fee as is determined by third party
insurers including but not limited to Medicare, Medicaid and other private,
public and commercial insurance carriers.
      (2)   In the event of a disagreement or disputed charge, the City Manager
shall have the authority to make final determination.
   (b)   All revenue for emergency ambulance services collected shall be used
for the purpose of providing, maintaining and improving emergency fire and
medical services within the Municipality.
(Ord. 01-3. Passed 1-23-01.)

244.01 DIRECTOR OF SERVICE; COMPOSITION OF DEPARTMENT.
   The Department of Service shall be under the direction of the Director of
Service, who shall perform duties as set forth in these Codified Ordinances and
as directed by the City Manager. The Department shall include the following
Divisions:
   (a)   The Division of Maintenance;
   (b)   The Division of Utilities; and
   (c)   The Division of Engineering.
244.02 DIVISION OF MAINTENANCE.
   The Division of Maintenance shall be under the direction of the
Superintendent of Maintenance, who shall be accountable to the Director of
Service. There may be one or more foremen under the direction of the
Superintendent. The Division shall perform the following functions:
   (a)   Maintain, repair, construct, improve and extend the public streets and
storm sewerage systems of the City;
   (b)   Erect, construct, apply and maintain all street signs and traffic
control signs and markings within the public rights of way;
   (c)   Perform other duties required by the Director of Service or the City
Manager;
   (d)   Maintain and operate all cemeteries under the control of the City;
   (e)   Maintain accurate records of all operations, including plat maps,
ownership of lots and interments;
   (f)   Submit reports to the Director of Service or the City Manager as
required or requested;
   (g)   Provide for necessary services in connection with burials;
   (h)   Furnish custodial service for all buildings owned and operated by the
City, the responsibility for which custodial services is not specifically
allocated to some other department, division or section;
   (i)   Maintain and repair all buildings and grounds owned and operated by
the City, the responsibility for which maintenance and repair is not
specifically allocated to some other department, division or section; and
   (j)   Maintain and repair all equipment owned and operated by the City, the
responsibility for which maintenance and repair is not specifically allocated
to some other department, division or section.
(Ord. 75-18. Passed 3-25-75. )
244.03 DIVISION OF UTILITIES.
   The Division of Utilities shall be under the direction of the Superintendent
of Utilities, who shall be accountable to the Director of Service. The Division
shall be composed of the Utilities Plant Section and the Utilities Maintenance
Section.
(Ord. 75-18. Passed 3-25-75. )
244.04 UTILITIES PLANT SECTION.
   The Utilities Plant Section shall be under the direction of the Utilities
Plant Supervisor, who shall be appointed from time to time by the City Manager
and who shall be accountable to the Superintendent of Utilities. The Utilities
Plant Section shall have the following functions
   (a)   Operate, maintain and repair the water production plant of the City,
including the buildings used by the same and the wells, treatment facilities
and other appurtenances related to the production and treatment of water;
   (b)   Operate, maintain and repair the sewage treatment plant of the City,
including the buildings used by the same;
   (c)   Maintain accurate records of all operations, including quantities of
water pumped and records of treatment;
   (d)   Perform other duties required by the Superintendent of Utilities or
the Director of Service; and
   (e)   Submit reports to the Superintendent of Utilities, the Director of
Service or the City Manager, as required or requested.
(Ord. 75-18. Passed 3-25-75. )
244.05 UTILITIES MAINTENANCE SECTION.
   The Utilities Maintenance Section shall be under the direction of the
Utilities Maintenance Supervisor, who shall be appointed from time to time by
the City Manager and who shall be accountable to the Superintendent of
Utilities. The Utilities Maintenance Section shall have the following
functions:
   (a)   Operate, maintain and repair the water distribution system of the
City, including the buildings used by the same and the valves, meters, tanks
and fire hydrants, and distribute water through such system as pumped by the
City from its wells to the residents, hydrants and other places where such
water is used;
   (b)   Maintain accurate records of all operations, including quantities of
water sold to consumers, and make available to the Department of Finance the
information necessary to render invoices to customers for water used and
services rendered;
   (c)   Operate, maintain and repair the sanitary sewers of the City,
including pumping stations and other appurtenances;
   (d)   Furnish, operate and maintain for all City buildings and installations
the necessary pipe, fixtures and services necessary to water sewage;
   (e)   Perform other duties required by the Superintendent of Utilities or
the Director of Service; and
   (f)   Submit reports to the Superintendent of Utilities, the Director of
Service, or the City Manager, as required or requested.
(Ord. 75-18. Passed 3-25-75. )
244.06 DIVISION OF ENGINEERING.
   The Division of Engineering shall be under the direction of the Director of
Service. The Division shall have the following functions:
   (a)   Perform or direct engineering services for City capital improvement
projects;
   (b)   Perform or direct traffic engineering services for the City;
   (c)   Provide engineering services to other departments, divisions or
sections, as required or requested;
   (d)   Administer and enforce the Subdivision Regulations and the Official
Thoroughfare Plan;
   (e)   Administer and enforce regulations relative to drainage and erosion
and sedimentation control;
   (f)   Administer and enforce regulations relative to construction, use and
improvement of public works;
   (g)   Coordinate with all other departments, divisions and sections as
appropriate to ensure orderly planning and construction;
   (h)   Administer and inspect the installation of street lighting;
   (i)   Administer and enforce the regulations relative to sidewalk and curb
maintenance;
   (j)   Perform other duties required by the City Manager; and
   (k)   Submit reports to the City Manager, as required or requested.
(Ord. 75-18. Passed 3-25-75. )

248.01 ESTABLISHMENT; COMPOSITION.
   There is hereby established a Department of Community and Economic
Development for the City, to be composed of a Director and such other personnel
as Council from time to time determines to be necessary.
(Ord. 79-65. Passed 12-11-79.)
248.02 DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Department of Community and Economic Development shall be under the
direction of the Director of Community and Economic Development who shall be
named by the City Manager and who shall perform duties as set forth in these
Codified Ordinances and as directed by the City Manager. The Director shall be
responsible for formulating policies and implementing strategies related to the
long and short-range physical development of the City, including the
administration of planning, code enforcement, community development and
economic development activities.
(Ord. 79-65. Passed 12-11-79.)
248.03 DUTIES OF DIRECTOR.
   The Director of Community and Economic Development shall perform the
following functions:
   (a)   Direct the City's economic development program with prospective
industries, developers, financial institutions, City staff, chambers of
commerce and other development agencies;
   (b)   Direct the long-range and current community development program,
including preparation of planning reports, implementation of development
controls and preparation of Federal, State and local grant programs;
   (c)   Assist the Director of Finance and the City Manager in preparing the
annual analyses of revenues and expenditures and updating the capital
improvements program and budget;
   (d)   Serve as the Secretary-Treasurer for the Community Improvement
Corporation and provide staff assistance to the Planning Commission, as well as
liaison with Council and City staff;
   (e)   Direct the Division of Code Enforcement in the administration of City
codes and ordinances;
   (f)   Administer the Department, including formulating and recommending to
the City Manager policies, procedures, rules and regulations for the operation
of the City and the Department relative to the Director's responsibilities;
   (g)   Direct the assignment of departmental personnel and provide for their
training; and
   (h)   Perform such other duties as the City Manager may prescribe.
(Ord. 79-65. Passed 12-11-79.)
248.04 DIVISION OF CODE ENFORCEMENT.
   The Division of Code Enforcement shall be under the direction of the
Director of Community and Economic Development and shall perform the following
functions:
   (a)   Administer and enforce the Zoning Code, including the Sign Ordinance (
Chapter 1280), the Landscape Regulations (
Chapter 1224), the Subdivision Regulations and all other general regulations
relative to the use and occupancy of property and the development of land in
the City's jurisdiction;
   (b)   Maintain copies of building permits, zoning permits, certificates of
occupancy and other permits related to the use of property and the development
of land;
   (c)   Review plans and specifications for building construction and public
improvements and inspect these projects, while under construction, for
compliance with City codes;
   (d)   Investigate code violations and prepare necessary action for
compliance;
   (e)   Coordinate with other agencies for health and housing code
enforcement;
   (f)   Coordinate with other departments and divisions, as appropriate, to
ensure orderly building and development in the City;
   (g)   Perform other duties required by the Director or the City Manager; and
   (h)   Submit reports to the Director or the City Manager, as required or
requested.
(Ord. 79-65. Passed 12-11-79.)
248.05 ENGLEWOOD COMMUNITY IMPROVEMENT CORPORATION.
   (a)   The Englewood Community Improvement Corporation, a community
improvement corporation organized and existing as a corporation not for profit
under the laws of the State, is hereby designated by the City as the agent and
instrumentality of the City for the industrial, commercial, distribution and
research development in the City.
   (b)   The plan of industrial, commercial, distribution and research
development for the City, which has been presented to Council by the Englewood
Community Improvement Corporation, is hereby confirmed and the proper agents of
the City are hereby authorized and directed to execute and deliver any consent
to the plan and to enter into any necessary agreements required by law to
effectuate such plan in cooperation with the Englewood Community Improvement
Corporation.
(Ord. 79-64. Passed 11-27-79.)
248.06 DIRECTOR AS WAGE COORDINATOR FOR CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)   The Director of Community and Economic Development is hereby
designated as the prevailing wage coordinator for City construction projects
begun after December 17, 1980, and financed in whole or in part by industrial
revenue bonds endorsed by the City.
   (b)   The prevailing wage coordinator shall perform all the duties specified
by Ohio R.C. 4115.071, and fees for this purpose shall be paid to him or her
from the application fees paid to the Community Improvement Corporation in
conjunction with bond endorsement.
   (c)   The duties of the prevailing wage coordinator shall cease upon a
determination that such duties will be performed by the State Department of
Industrial Relations or other authorized agency.
(Res. 49-81. Passed 5-12-81.)
248.07 FIRE INSURANCE PROCEEDS; RESPONSIBILITY OF DIRECTOR.
   (a)   The City hereby adopts and accepts the provisions and procedures set
forth in Ohio R.C. 3929.86, particularly subsections (C) and (D) thereof,
providing for the transfer and receipt of portions of fire insurance proceeds
as set forth in such section.
   (b)   The Director of Community Development is hereby designated as the
officer of the City authorized to carry out the duties under Ohio R.C. 3929.86.
(Ord. 81-39. Passed 10-13-81.)
248.08 EXERCISE OF POWERS OF EMINENT DOMAIN.
   (a)   Economic development is formally recognized as a valid public purpose
in connection with the City's exercise of its constitutional powers of eminent
domain.
   (b)   The City is hereby authorized to exercise its constitutional power of
eminent domain purely for the purpose of economic development within the City.
   (c)   This section is not intended to modify in any way the legal procedures
required in order for the City to exercise its eminent domain powers. Any use
of eminent domain for economic development purposes shall follow all customary
statutory procedures required in connection with the exercise of such right.
(Ord. 00-4. Passed 4-11-00.)

249.02 HUMAN SERVICES DIRECTOR; RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Department of Human Service shall be under the direction of the Human
Services Director, who shall be appointed by the City Manager and who shall
perform duties as set forth in these Codified Ordinances and as directed by the
City Manager. The Director shall be responsible for the administration of the
Earl Heck Community Center and coordination of community activities there.
(Ord. 91-5. Passed 3-12-91.)
249.03 DUTIES OF DIRECTOR.
   The Human Services Director shall perform the following functions:
   (a)   Oversee the daily operation of the Earl Heck Community Center;
   (b)   Coordinate and schedule use of the Community Center for recreation,
classes, meetings and parties;
   (c)   Organize, supervise, and participate in the Northmont Rent-A-Kid
Program; recruit and train participants, receive requests for Rent-A-Kid
workers and assign workers to jobs;
   (d)   Organize recreational and educational classes for various age groups
at the Community Center, arrange for instructors and collect registration fees;
   (e)   Organize, supervise and participate in special programs for various
age groups at the Community Center;
   (f)   Supervise activities of visitors during periods of open recreation at
the Community Center;
   (g)   Schedule use of the City's baseball diamonds and soccer fields;
   (h)   Act as the City's representative to the Montgomery County Council on
Aging and the Miami Valley Parks and Recreation Association;
   (i)   Promote use of the Community Center by the general public for private
parties and meetings;
   (j)   Aid senior citizens in obtaining social services and available through
other private or government agencies; and
   (k)   Perform such other duties as the City Manager may prescribe.
(Ord. 91-5. Passed 3-12-91.)

252.01 SURETY BONDS.
   In accordance with Section
9.02 of the City Charter, all employees of the City whose duties require them
to handle or be concerned with the management of its money or other property
shall furnish to the Clerk of Council a corporate surety bond issued by a
company authorized to do business in Ohio, to protect the City against loss due
to their acts. The premiums of such bonds shall be paid from the funds of the
Municipality. Such bonds shall be in the amount of five thousand dollars
($5,000.00) each. All other officers or employees shall be covered by a two
thousand five hundred dollar ($2,500.00) blanket bond.
(Ord. 72-35. Passed 11-14-72.)
252.02 AGREEMENTS TO ASSIGN WAGES AUTHORIZED.
   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized, from time to time, to enter
into agreements and contracts with the employees of the Municipality, whether
they are elected or appointed, to assign a portion of their wages to third
parties under the provisions and limitations of Ohio R.C. 1321.31 and 1321.32
and other applicable provisions of law. The Director may then withhold payment
of such assigned portion of the wages of such employees and pay such portions
to the authorized third parties under the provisions of this section and
applicable law.
(Ord. 571. Passed 11-19-68.)
252.03 BONUS FOR EXCEPTIONAL QUALIFICATIONS.
   The City Manager may elect to award additional compensation in the amount of
up to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) maximum per grade annually to an
employee who may qualify by special training to improve his or her skills
resulting in increased value to his or her employer.
(Ord. 686. Passed 12-15-70.)
252.04 PAYMENT OF COMPENSATION.
   Compensation shall be payable in apportioned installments every other Friday
for compensation earned through the previous Sunday.
(Ord. 73-43. Passed 11-27-73.)
252.05 PART-TIME OR TEMPORARY HELP.
   The City Manager is authorized to appoint persons to part-time or temporary
positions of employment with the City within the limits of appropriations.
(Ord. 71-65. Passed 12-28-71.)
252.06 GROUP HEALTH CARE PLAN.
   (a)   As an additional benefit for full-time regular and probationary
employees, the City will provide a group health care plan(s) to include
medical, hospitalization and major medical, prescription drug, and dental
benefits. Payment for the premiums of such health care plan(s) shall be shared
by the City and participating employees at a percentage deemed reasonable and
appropriate by a Benefits Committee consisting of the Director of Personnel,
the Director of Finance, and the City Manager.
   (b)   The group health care plan(s) may consist of a fully insured benefit
program, a self-insured benefit program, or any combination thereof. The City
Manager is hereby authorized to utilize the services of a broker, agent, or
consultant in the collection of proposals and/or administration of said plan
(s). Level of benefits; employee premium contributions, co-pays, deductibles,
and out-of-pocket maximums and features of the plan(s) shall be reviewed on an
annual basis and maybe adjusted in accordance with the cost of such plan(s) and
the financial resources of the City.
   (c)   All full-time regular and probationary employees will be eligible to
participate in the group health care plan(s) from the time of their appointment
until such time as they are separated from employment, or are no longer in a
full-time employment status. Part-time employees shall not be eligible to
participate in the group health care plan(s). The premiums for the provided
benefits, except for that portion of employee contributions, shall be paid from
the same funds of the City which provide the wages for each participating
employee.
(Ord. 03-15. Passed 8-26-03.)
252.07 GROUP LIFE INSURANCE.
   (a)   The City, as an additional benefit for regular and probationary
employees, will pay all of the costs of one or more group life insurance plans
providing term life and accidental death and dismemberment insurance coverage
for such employees, excluding elected officials and the Law Director. No
employee of the City shall acquire any cash surrender value or other interest
in and to such insurance unless such benefits are provided for by the contract
between the City and such insurance company with which the City enters into
such contract. All covered employees will be eligible for such coverage and
insurance from the time of their employment by the City, the benefit actually
to be available to them according to the policy. The premiums for the provided
group life insurance shall be paid from the several funds of the City. The
benefits of such insurance, if provided for by the contract in force at any
time, may continue under the waiver of premium provisions of the policy, in the
event of total and permanent disability, even though such employee is removed
from the payroll of the City because of such disability.
(Ord. 87-25. Passed 8-11-87.)
   (b)   The City Manager shall cause this matter to be reviewed each time the
insurance contract is to be renewed and shall report to Council the estimated
annual premium to be paid for the next ensuing year before the insurance is
renewed.
   (c)   The City Manager is not necessarily directed by this section to renew
this insurance coverage with the same company each and every year, but he or
she is directed to attempt to renew this coverage with a reputable insurance
company and at the best price obtainable.
(Ord. 82-37. Passed 12-28-82.)
252.08 SUPPLEMENTAL INSURANCE.
   The City Manager is hereby authorized to contract for supplemental employee
group insurance and to cause payment for such insurance to be made from payroll
deductions levied and collected from covered employees. Such insurance may be
provided to all eligible employees in a group so requesting.
(Ord. 75-23. Passed 4-22-75.)
252.085 GROUP HEALTH BENEFITS.
   (a)   Effective January 1, 2000, there is hereby adopted in and for the City
the Premium Only Plan ("the Plan") for the provision of certain group health
benefits to City employees. A copy of the Plan is attached to original
Resolution 52-99, passed November 23, 1999, as Addendum A.
   (b)   A Benefits Committee is hereby established, consisting of the Director
of Personnel, the Director of Finance and the City Manager.
   (c)   The City Manager, or his or her designee, is hereby authorized and
directed to execute, acknowledge and deliver any and all instruments or
documents, and to take any and all other steps as may be deemed necessary or
desirable, in his or her sole discretion, to carry out the intent and purpose
of this section.
(Res. 52-99. Passed 11-23-99.)
