1044.01 REVENUE AND EXPENSES.
   All revenue derived from or obtained in the course of the operation of the
water system shall be placed to the credit of the Water Fund in the accounts of
the City from which the costs and expenses of the water system shall be paid,
except as provided by Council from time to time.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.02 NO GUARANTEE OF SUPPLY.
   Because variable conditions may arise in the operation and maintenance of
the water system, the supply of water to consumers is without guarantee of a
fixed quantity, quality, purity or temperature.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.03 PROHIBITED USES, INADEQUATE SUPPLY.
   When the supply of water to the water system is inadequate for any reason to
meet the demand for water, the City Manager shall declare that the use of water
for lawn or garden, commercial laundries, swimming pools, manufacturing,
cooling, vehicle washing or other purpose not essential to the health, safety
and welfare of the residents of the City, is prohibited during specified hours,
during a specified time period or until notice is given as provided herein that
such use is permitted, and notice of such prohibitions on the use of water for
the above purposes shall be given in the same manner as provided for the
posting of ordinances.
   No person shall use water from the water system for lawn or garden,
manufacturing, agriculture, cooling, vehicle washing or other purposes not
essential to the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the City when
the City Manager has prohibited such use as provided herein.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.04 SHUTOFF FOR MAINTENANCE OR REPAIR.
   Water supply through the City's water mains may be shut off without notice
to consumers if breaks in mains, pumping equipment breakdown, reservoir
failures, construction, reconstruction, repair, replacement, cleaning,
extending or tapping of mains requires, and no claims for damages of any nature
whatsoever arising from such action will be paid.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.05 DAMAGE OR OBSTRUCTION; CROSS CONNECTIONS; UNAUTHORIZED CONNECTION TAPS.
   The City shall hold any consumer or other person responsible for damage to
the water system. No person shall obstruct the water system or make any cross
connection between the water system and any other source of water. No person
shall make any connection tap or draw water from the water system without first
having received the permits to do so required in this chapter and in
Chapter 1040.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.06 UNAUTHORIZED SALE OF WATER.
   No person shall sell water from the water system to another person for any
purpose, but this section shall not be construed to prohibit the payment of
water charges by one person for the benefit of another.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.07 FIRE HYDRANTS.
   No person shall operate or draw water from fire hydrants except in the
performance of his or her duties as a firefighter or as authorized by the
Superintendent of Utilities.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.08 OPENING COCKS OR STOPS.
   No person shall operate any corporation cock or stop except in the
performance of a test by a licensed plumber or as authorized by the
Superintendent of Utilities.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.09 WATER METERS.
   (a)   Water meters remain the property of the City at all times.
   (b)   No person shall break or tamper with the seal on any water meter
except as authorized by the Superintendent of Utilities.
   (c)   Water meters damaged by misuse, accident or any other act will be
repaired or replaced by the City and the cost of such repair or replacement
shall be charged to the owner or consumer of the premises served by the damaged
meter as are water charges.
   (d)   No person shall remove any meter except as authorized by the
Superintendent of Utilities.
   (e)   Any meter may be removed or replaced by the Division of Utilities for
tests, repairs or other purpose.
   (f)   Owners and consumers shall maintain the premises served to permit free
access to water meters.
   (g)   The Division of Utilities, as its work schedule permits, will relocate
any water meter to a water meter box or wall install a remote register device,
at the option of the Superintendent, when a property owner requests such
relocation or installation and pays to the City an amount equal to the cost of
such relocation or installation.
   (h)   The Division of Utilities may disconnect the supply of water to an
owner or consumer when the owner's or consumer's water service line or water
distribution system leaks unreasonably and such water supply shall not be
reconnected until the water service line or water distribution system is
repaired to a good condition.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
   (i)   Any consumer questioning the operating efficiency of his or her meter
may request that the meter be pulled and tested by the Division of Utilities.
If test results indicate that the meter is operating within the normal
efficiency range, the meter shall be reinstalled and a service charge of fifty
dollars ($50.00) shall be levied upon the consumer's account. However, if the
meter test indicates that the meter is operating beyond the normal efficiency
range, the defective meter shall be replaced and the consumer's billing shall
be adjusted to reflect an estimated consumption based upon an average of
previous billing periods.
(Ord. 83-3. Passed 1-11-83; Ord. 06-15. Passed 12-12-06; Ord. 10-16. Passed 12-
14-10.)
   (j)   A separate meter, to be newly installed for watering grass and other
landscaping, commonly referred to as a "sprinkling meter," shall be permitted
for installation at the owner's expense in compliance with all applicable
regulations.
(Ord. 89-18. Passed 4-25-89; Ord. 92-23. Passed 7-14-92.)
1044.10 CHARGES FOR WATER SUPPLIED WITHIN THE CITY.
   Each consumer or owner whose premises within the City is connected to the
water system shall pay to the City for the connection and for water at the rate
of not less than thirty-one dollars and eight cents ($31.08) bimonthly for each
dwelling, commercial, manufacturing or other unit served, plus six dollars and
twenty-three cents ($6.23) per 1,000 gallons of water delivered bimonthly over
5,000 gallons for each such unit served.
(Ord. 98-22. Passed 12-22-98; Ord. 00-22. Passed 11-28-00; Ord. 01-30. Passed
12-11-01; Ord. 02-20. Passed 12-10-02; Ord. 04-27. Passed 12-14-04; Ord. 05-31.
Passed 11-22-05; Ord. 06-15. Passed 12-12-06; Ord. 07-14. Passed 11-27-07; Ord.
09-14. Passed 12-8-09; Ord. 10-16. Passed 12-15-10; Ord. 11-14. Passed 12-13-
11; Ord. 12-12. Passed 11-13-12; Ord. 13-15. Passed 11-12- 13; Ord. 14-11.
Passed 12-9-14; Ord. 15-16. Passed 10-27-15; Ord. 16-18. Passed 12-13-16; Ord.
17-09. Passed 11-14-17; Ord. 18-18. Passed 11-13-18; Ord. 19-19. Passed 11-12-
19; Ord. 20-12. Passed 10-27-20; Ord. 22-02. Passed 1-11-22; Ord. 22-21. Passed
12-13-22; Ord. 23-12. Passed 11-14-23.)
1044.11 CHARGES FOR WATER SUPPLIED OUTSIDE THE CITY.
   Each consumer or owner whose premises outside the City is connected to the
water system shall pay to the City for the connection and for water at the rate
of not less than forty-six dollars and sixty-three cents ($46.63) bimonthly for
each dwelling, commercial, manufacturing or other unit served, plus nine
dollars and thirty-five cents ($9.35) per 1,000 gallons of water delivered
bimonthly over 5,000 gallons for each such unit served.
(Ord. 98-22. Passed 12-22-98; Ord. 00-22. Passed 11-28-00; Ord. 01-30. Passed
12-11-01; Ord. 02-20. Passed 12-10-02; Ord. 04-27. Passed 12-14-04; Ord. 05-31.
Passed 11-22-05; Ord. 06-15. Passed 12-12-06; Ord. 07-14. Passed 11-27-07; Ord.
09-14. Passed 12-8-09; Ord. 10-16. Passed 12-15-10; Ord. 11-14. Passed 12-13-
11; Ord. 12-12. Passed 11-13-12; Ord. 13-15. Passed 11-12- 13; Ord. 14-11.
Passed 12-9-14; Ord. 15-16. Passed 10-27-15; Ord. 16-18. Passed 12-13-16; Ord.
17-09. Passed 11-14-17; Ord. 18-18. Passed 11-13-18; Ord. 19-19. Passed 11-12-
19; Ord. 20-12. Passed 10-27-20; Ord. 22-02. Passed 1-11-22; Ord. 22-21. Passed
12-13-22; Ord. 23-12. Passed 11-14-23.)
1044.12 CHARGE FOR WATER SUPPLIED TO CONTAINERS.
   For water delivered to containers directly from the water system, the
purchaser shall pay a charge to the City at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00)
per 1,000 gallons with a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) minimum before such water
is delivered.
(Ord. 80-33. Passed 6-10-80; Ord. 07-14. Passed 11-27-07; Ord. 14-11. Passed
12-9-14; Ord. 15- 16. Passed 10-27-15; Ord. 16-18. Passed 12-13-16.)
1044.13 STATEMENTS; DELINQUENCIES; PENALTIES; DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE.
   Statements of the charges for water service shall be rendered bimonthly on
or about the twentieth day of the billing month for each consumer, as
determined by the Director of Finance, and the amount of all such charges shall
be paid to the City on or before ten days after the last day of the month in
which the statements are rendered. If the unpaid charges are not paid on or
before ten days after the last day of the month in which the statement was
rendered, an additional late payment charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00)
shall be added thereto and become part of such unpaid charges, and notice of
such additional charges shall be given in the manner provided for charges for
water service. If the unpaid charges are not paid on or before the last day of
the month following the month in which statements were rendered, the water
supply to the consumer so in default of payment shall be disconnected by the
City. When any water supply has been disconnected because of the consumer’s
failure to pay the charges provided herein, the consumer shall pay thirty-five
dollars ($35.00) as the fee for having the water supply reconnected. If
reconnection is required outside of regular business hours, the reconnection
fee shall be doubled.
(Ord. 80-57. Passed 11-11-80; Ord. 06-15. Passed 12-12-06; Ord. 10-16. Passed
12-14-10; Ord. 19-07. Passed 6-25-19.)
1044.14 NO REBATE FOR LEAKS.
   No deductions shall be made or rebate allowed to any consumer of water by or
on account of wasted water, leakage or alleged leakage in any water pipe, tank
or other apparatus or device. The amount of water registered by any meter shall
be charged and paid for in full, irrespective of whether such water, after
having been registered, was wasted, lost by leakage, accident or otherwise.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.15 CONNECTION PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Before any connection is made for the use or delivery of water from the
water system to a consumer, the owner of the property to be served or the
consumer shall apply to the Department of Finance for a connection permit
which, after the fees and charges required in this chapter have been paid to
the City and the plans, information, documents and assurances required herein
have been submitted to the City, shall be issued by the Director of Finance.
The Division of Utilities shall within a reasonable time thereafter make such
connection in the manner provided in this chapter, provided that any required
installation charges under this chapter are paid.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.16 PERMIT APPLICATION INFORMATION.
   Applications for connection permits shall be made in a form required by the
Director of Finance and shall contain such information necessary to determine
the ownership, location, use or proposed use of the property to be served, the
amount of water likely to be required by the consumer, the location. of the
building or other point of use on the property and such other information,
plans, documents and assurances required by the Director of Finance to process
the application.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.17 CONNECTION PERMIT FEES.
   The following shall be the schedule of fees for connections to the water
system. Before any person connects to or draws water from the water system or
extends the use of water on his or her premises to an additional dwelling,
commercial, manufacturing or other unit or area, or in the same unit or area,
he or she shall pay to the City a connection permit fee in an amount applicable
to the schedule below.
   (a)   For all connections to the water system or extensions thereof, the fee
shall be an amount established for the larger of either the tap itself or the
meter therefor, per the schedule below, but in no case shall such fee be less
than four hundred and fifty dollars ($450.00).

   (b)   For each addition to a use, requiring a separate water connection, a

   (c)   For purposes of determining, the size and number of meters required

1044.18 SERVICE AND PRIVILEGES AUTHORIZED BY CONNECTION PERMIT.
   An approved connection permit authorizes a property owner or consumer to
connect to and use water from the water system as permitted herein and as
restricted by the City from time to time and in a like manner and with the same
privileges as other consumers connected to the water system. The City shall
furnish a corporation stop and tap the water main serving the property owner's
or consumer's premises. The City shall furnish, install, own and maintain a
water meter of a size for which a permit fee has been paid and, when the water
service line and appurtenances have been installed and approved, shall maintain
a water service line and appurtenances from the water main to its connection
with the owner's or consumer's service line at the water meter or ground key
curb stop, but in no case will the City maintain any part of a service line
located on an owner's or consumer's premises.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.19 RESPONSIBILITIES OF PROPERTY OWNER OR CONSUMER.
   The property owner or consumer shall be responsible for all costs of
materials and work necessary to install a water service line and appurtenances
in accordance with the Montgomery County Uniform Building Code, as adopted in
Chapter 1420 of Part Fourteen - the Building and Housing Code, which shall
begin at the corporation stop, and continue to or onto the property served or
point of use, including a stop to be located on the water main side of the
water meter in an approved stop or meter box at the point of entry onto the
premises to be served, an approved meter set and an approved meter box if the
meter is installed outside a building and further shall provide an approved
tapping saddle if required.
   The property owner or consumer shall expose the water main at the point to
be tapped.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.20 METER LOCATION; BOXES; SERVICE LINES.
   Water meters, unless otherwise authorized by the Superintendent of
Utilities, shall be located in meter boxes consisting of a tile not less than
twenty inches in diameter and covered with an approved top, Ford Type C or
equal. Meter boxes shall not be constructed in or under any rigid paving
materials without permission of the Superintendent.
   All water service lines shall be not less than three and one-half feet below
finished grade at any point. When sanitary sewer ditches are used for
installation of water service lines, a distance of at least one and one-half
feet above and to either side of such sanitary sewer line shall be maintained
at all points of installation, or the water service line shall be installed in
a separate ditch or trench at a distance of not less than two feet from any
ditch or trench which has been used for a sanitary sewer.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.21 METER LOCATION EXCEPTION.
   The Superintendent of Utilities may authorize the installation of water
meters inside structures in a frost-proof location when the property owner or
consumer pays to the City, as the fee for installation by the City of a remote
meter register and connections at a point on the exterior of the structure, an
amount equal to the cost to the City of materials, labor and equipment required
to install the register and connection devices.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.22 UNAUTHORIZED CONNECTIONS.
   No person shall make any tap or connection to the water system without a
permit therefor and except as authorized by the Director of Service or his or
her representative. Water usage meters shall only be set after, or allowed to
remain in place if, service lines and devices, including backflow prevention,
have met current inspection standards established by the Director.
(Ord. 98-15. Passed 9-8-98.)
1044.23 CENTER HUB STAKES; LOCATION OF TAPS, SERVICE MAINS AND BOXES.
   No water connection shall be made for any lot unless there is first set on
the premises a center hub stake with relation to the lot for which the
connection is sought.
   Every water connection shall be made from the water main at a position
opposite the center hub stake for the lot to be served, unless a tap at such
position would place the water line in violation of the provisions of Section
1044.20, in which case the tap may be made at such position as the
Superintendent of Utilities shall direct.
   Service mains, including replacements to premises, shall be run at right
angles to the street and at a depth of not less than three and one-half feet
below the finished grade.
   Water meter boxes and ground key curb stop boxes shall be located at a point
approximately equal distance between the back of the curb and the edge of the
sidewalk nearest the curb.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.24 PEAK DEMAND FLOW.
   The water service connection and water service line to the premises to be
served shall be of sufficient size as determined by accepted engineering
practice to furnish an adequate flow of water to meet the requirements of the
consumer at peak demand and in no case less than three-quarter inch nominal
diameter.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.25 SEPARATE CONNECTIONS REQUIRED.
   Each separate single or multifamily dwelling structure, each separate
commercial, manufacturing or other structure, unless occupied by a single
commercial, manufacturing or other consumer on the same lot, parcel or tract of
land, and each lot, parcel or tract of land, shall be connected to the water
system separately and water delivered to each shall be individually metered and
water charges individually computed.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.26 INSPECTION BEFORE APPROVAL.
   The Department of Service shall inspect all service connections and lines
and shall not approve the delivery of water through the service connection or
line unless the service connection and line have been installed in conformity
with approved standards for materials and workmanship. The fee for such
inspection shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per thirty-five linear feet or part
thereof.
(Ord. 78-26. Passed 4-11-78.)
1044.27 EXTENSIONS GENERALLY.
   Water distribution mains may be extended in the City by one of the three
following methods:
   (a)   Special assessments basis as per Ohio R.C. Chapter 727;
   (b)   Installation charge basis as set out in this chapter; and
   (c)   Requirement for development as set out in the Subdivision Regulations.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1044.28 INSTALLATION CHARGES GENERALLY.
   (a)   Concurrent with the payment of a connection fee to the City by any
owner or consumer who hereafter taps into the water system constructed or
hereafter constructed pursuant to this section, there shall be paid an
installation charge equal to the fair share of the cost of labor, equipment and
materials for the installation of such water line adjacent to the property of
such owner or consumer, in accordance with the provisions of this section, in
addition to the required connection fee.
   (b)   Council may, from time to time by resolution, find and declare that
the actual cost of the installation of any water line may be paid for under the
provisions of this chapter. Such resolution shall apportion the actual cost of
the installation of such water line, including labor, equipment and materials,
among the several owners or consumers who may be benefited thereby, according
to the front foot method. Such resolution shall declare that in lieu of an
assessment against such property owners, at the time of the actual installation
of such water line, the cost thereof will not be assessed at the time of the
actual installation of such water line, but may be paid by any owner or
consumer benefited thereby at such time as he may actually connect to such
water line. The resolution shall further provide for the actual front foot
charge to be made for the installation of such water line and further provide
for the amount of interest which will be credited and accumulated on such
installation charge from the time of the installation of the water line to the
time such charge may be paid by any owner or consumer.
   (c)   A map of the City and environs shall be established and the same shall
be posted in the most public place on the interior of the Municipal Building
giving notice to all persons who may be interested of those areas and tracts of
land in the City and environs which are subject to an additional water line
installation charge, a charge in addition to other charges made for tapping
into the City water lines. All water line installation charges established and
not paid shall be entered upon a map by showing those areas in color and all
areas made subject to an installation charge in the future shall be indicated
on such map in color.
   The Director of Finance shall keep the map up to date and shall indicate on
the map, as aforesaid, which areas are subject to charge and also those areas
where the charge has been paid.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71., )
1044.29 SPECIAL INSTALLATION CHARGES.
   (a)   Concurrent with the payment to the City of a tap-in fee by any
resident or business organization who or which utilizes taps into the 2,800-
foot, sixteen-inch water main constructed in November, 1987, between Wenger
Road and Hiligrove Avenue, such resident or business organization shall pay an
installation charge to pay the fair share of the installation cost of the water
line, in addition to the normal tap-in fee, computed as set forth in subsection
(b) hereof.
   (b)   Such charge shall be the lesser of either three thousand, five
hundred, twenty-five dollars (3,525) per gross acre, or part thereof,
comprising the zoning lot to be developed or sixty cents (60Q) per square foot
of gross floor area, per floor, of the principal building erected on the zoning
lot.
   (c)   The same additional charge computation and fee shall apply to a new
tap of the eight-inch water line which parallels the newly constructed sixteen-
inch main.
   (d)   Charges to be collected under this section will no longer be
applicable after ten years from the effective date of this section.
(Ord. 87-29. Passed 10-13-87.)
1044.30 STANDARDS FOR CONSTRUCTION.
   All methods, materials and appurtenances used in water mains, extensions and
installations shall be in conformity with accepted engineering practice,
including standards for such installation promulgated by the American Water
Works Association.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71. )
1044.31 WATER EMERGENCIES.
   In the event of drought, disaster or any other emergency demanding an
immediate response to protect the water supply and public interest, the City
Manager shall be granted full and immediate authority to impose voluntary and/
or mandatory watering restrictions and any other measures as he or she may deem
necessary. No person shall violate or fail to comply with any watering ban or
other such restriction or measure.
(Ord. 89-18. Passed 4-25-89.)
1044.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter or any rule, regulation or order promulgated pursuant to this chapter
is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than sixty days, or both,
for each offense. Except where otherwise provided, a separate offense shall be
deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance
occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 1048
Water System Cross-Connection Control

prevention devices.

1048.01 PURPOSES.
   The purposes of this chapter are to:
   (a)   Protect the public potable water supply from contamination or
pollution by isolating within a consumer's water system contaminants or
pollutants which could backflow through the service connection into the public
potable water system;
   (b)   Promote the elimination or control of existing cross-connections,
actual or potential, between the public or a consumer's potable water system
and nonpotable water systems, plumbing fixtures and sources or systems
containing process fluids; and
   (c)   Provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross-
connection control which will systematically and effectively prevent the
contamination or pollution of the public and any consumer's potable water
systems.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)
1048.02 APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   This chapter shall apply to all premises served by the public potable water
system of the City.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)
1048.03 RESPONSIBILITY OF SERVICE DIRECTOR; NOTICE TO INSTALL BACKFLOW
PREVENTION DEVICES.
   The Director of Service shall be responsible for protection of the public
potable water system from contamination due to backflow of contaminants through
the water service connection. If, in the judgment of the Director of Service,
or his or her authorized representative, an approved backflow prevention device
is necessary for the safety of the public water system, he or she shall give
notice to the consumer to install such approved backflow prevention device at
each service connection to his or her premises. The consumer shall immediately
install such approved device or devices at his or her own expense, and failure,
refusal or inability on the part of the consumer to install such device or
devices immediately shall constitute grounds for discontinuing water service to
the premises until such device or devices have been installed.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)
1048.04 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
      (1)   "Air gap separation" means the unobstructed vertical distance
through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet
supply water to a tank, plumbing fixture or other device and the flood level
rim of the receptacle.
      (2)   "Approved" means that a backflow prevention device or method has
been accepted by the water purveyor and the Director of the Ohio Environmental
Protection Agency as suitable for the proposed use.
      (3)   "Auxiliary water system" means any water system on or available to
the premises other than the public water system and includes the water supplied
by the system. These auxiliary waters may include water from another purveyor's
public water system; water from a source such as wells, lakes or streams;
process fluids; or used water. They may be polluted, contaminated,
objectionable or constitute a water source or system over which the water
purveyor does not have control.
      (4)   "Backflow" means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or
substances into the distributing pipes of a potable water supply from any
source other than the intended source of the potable water supply.
      (5)   "Backflow prevention device" means any device, method or type of
construction intended to prevent backflow into a potable water system.
      (6)   "Consumer" means the owner or person in control of any premises
supplied by, or in any manner connected to, a public water system.
      (7)   "Consumer's water system" means any water system located on the
consumer's premises, supplied by, or in any manner connected to, a public water
system. A household plumbing system is considered to be a consumer's water
system.
      (8)    "Contamination" means an impairment of the quality of the water by
sewage of process fluids or waste to a degree which could create an actual
hazard to the public health through poisoning or through spread of disease by
exposure.
      (9)    "Cross-connection" means any arrangement whereby backflow can
occur.
      (10)   "Degree of hazard" is a term derived from an evaluation of the
potential risk to health and the adverse effect upon the potable water system.
      (11)   "Director" means the Director of the Ohio Environmental Protection
Agency.
      (12)   "Director of Service" means the Director of the Service Department
of the City.
      (13)   "Double check valve assembly" means an assembly composed of two
single, independently acting, check valves, including tightly closing shut-off
valves located at each end of the assembly and suitable connections for testing
the watertightness of each check valve.
      (14)   "Health hazard" means any condition, device or practice in a water
system or its operation that creates, or may create, a danger to the health and
well being of users. "Severe, " as used to qualify "health hazard, " means a
hazard to the health of the user that could reasonably be expected to result in
significant morbidity or death.
      (15)   "Interchangeable connection" means an arrangement or device that
will allow alternate but not simultaneous use of two sources of water.
      (16)   "Nonpotable water" means water not safe for drinking, personal or
culinary use.
      (17)    "Person" means the State, any political subdivision, public or
private corporation, individual, partnership or other legal entity.
      (18)   "Pollution" means the presence in water of any foreign substance
that tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the
usefulness or quality of the water to a degree which does not create an actual
hazard to the public health but which does adversely and unreasonably affect
such waters for domestic use.
      (19)   "Potable water" means water which is satisfactory for drinking,
culinary and domestic purposes and meets the requirements of the Ohio
Environmental Protection Agency.
      (20)   "Process fluids" means any fluid or solution which may be
chemically, biologically or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or
concentration as would constitute a health, pollution or system hazard if
introduced into the public or a potable consumer's water system. This includes,
but is' not limited to:
         A.    Polluted or contaminated waters;
         B.   Process waters;
         C.   Used waters originating from the public water system which may
have deteriorated in sanitary quality;
         D.   Cooling waters;
         E.   Contaminated natural waters taken from wells, lakes, streams or
irrigation systems;
         F.   Chemicals in solution or suspension; and
         G.   Oils, gases, acids, alkalis and other liquid and gaseous fluids
used in industrial or other processes, or for fire-fighting purposes.
      (21)   "Public water system" means any publicly or private owned potable
water system subject to Ohio R. C. 6111.13.
      (22)   "Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device" means a
device containing a minimum of two independently acting check valves together
with an automatically operated pressure differential relief valve located
between the two check valves. During normal flow and at the cessation of normal
flow, the pressure between those two checks shall be less than the supply
pressure. In case of leakage of either check valve, the differential relief
valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall operate to maintain the pressure
between the check valves at less than the supply pressure. The unit must
include tightly closing shut-off valves located at each end of the device, and
each device shall be fitted with properly located test cocks.
      (23)   "Service connection" means the terminal end of a service line from
the public water system. If a meter is installed at the end of the service,
then the service connection means the downstream end of the meter.
      (24)   "System hazard" means a condition posing an actual or potential
threat of damage to the physical properties of the public water system or a
potable consumer's water system.
      (25)   "Pollution hazard" means a condition through which an
aesthetically objectionable or degrading material not dangerous to health may
enter the public water system or a potable consumer's water system.
      (26)   "Used water" means any water supplied by a water purveyor from a
public water system to a consumer's water system after it has passed through
the service connection and is no longer under the control of the water
purveyor.
      (27)   "Water purveyor" means the owner or operator of a public water
system.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)
1048.05 COMPONENTS OF WATER SYSTEM.
   The water system shall be considered as made up of two parts: the public
potable water system and the consumer's water system.
   (a)   The public potable water system consists of the source facilities and
the distribution system and includes all those facilities of the potable water
system under the control of the Director of Service up to the point where the
consumer's water system begins. The source shall include all components of the
facilities utilized in the production, treatment, storage and delivery of water
to the public distribution system. The public distribution system shall include
the network of conduits used for delivery of water from the source to the
consumer's water system.
   (b)   The consumer's water system shall include those parts of the
facilities beyond the service connection which are utilized in conveying water
from the public distribution system to points of use.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)
1048.06 CROSS-CONNECTIONS PROHIBITED.
   No water service connection shall be installed or maintained on any premises
where actual or potential cross-connections to the public potable or consumer's
water system may exist, unless such actual or potential cross-connections are
abated or controlled to the satisfaction of the Director of Service.
   No connection shall be installed or maintained whereby an auxiliary water
supply may enter a public potable or consumer's water system, unless such
auxiliary water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply have
been approved by the Director of Service and by the Director of the
Environmental Protection Agency as required by Ohio R. C. 6111.15.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)
1048.07 SURVEY AND INVESTIGATIONS.
   The consumer's premises shall be open at all reasonable times to the
Director of Service or his authorized representative, for the conduct of
surveys and investigations of water use practices within the consumer's
premises to determine whether there are actual or potential cross-connections
to the consumer's water system through which contamination or pollutants could
backflow into the public potable water system.
   On request by the Director of Service or his or her authorized
representative, the consumer shall furnish information on water use practices
within his or her premises.
   It shall be the responsibility of the water consumer to conduct periodic
surveys of water use practices on his or her premises to determine whether
there are actual or potential cross-connections to his or her water system
through which contaminants or pollutants could backflow into his or her or the
public potable water system.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)
1048.08 WHERE PROTECTION IS REQUIRED.
   (a)   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each
service line to a consumer's water system serving premises, where, in the
judgment of the Director of Service or the Director of the Ohio Environmental
Protection Agency, actual or potential hazards to the public potable water
system exist.
   (b)   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each
service line to a consumer's water system serving the following premises:
      (1)   Premises having an auxiliary water supply, unless such auxiliary
supply is accepted as an additional source by the Director of Service and the
source is approved by the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency;
      (2)   Premises on which any substance is handled in such a fashion as to
create an actual or potential hazard to the public potable water system. This
includes premises having sources or systems containing process fluids or waters
originating from the public potable water system which are no longer under the
sanitary control of the Director of Service.
      (3)   Premises having internal cross-connections that, in the judgment of
the Director of Service, are not correctable, or intricate plumbing
arrangements which make it impractical to determine whether or not cross-
connnections exist;
      (4)   Premises where, because of security requirements or other
prohibitions or restrictions, it is impossible or impractical to make a
complete crossconnection survey;
      (5)   Premises having a repeated history of cross-connections being
established or re-established; and
      (6)   Others specified by the Director of Service or the Director of the
Ohio Environmental Protection Agency.
   (c)   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each
service line to a consumer's water system serving, but not necessarily limited
to, the following types of facilities, unless the Director of Service or the
Director of the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency determines that no actual
or potential hazard to the public potable water system exists.
      (1)   Hospitals, mortuaries, clinics, nursing homes;
      (2)   Laboratories;
      (3)   Piers, docks, waterfront facilities;
      (4)   Sewage treatment plants, sewage pumping stations or storm water
pumping stations;
      (5)   Food or beverage processing plants;
      (6)   Chemical plants;
      (7)   Metal plating industries;
      (8)   Petroleum processing or storage plants;
      (9)   Radioactive material processing plants or nuclear reactors;
      (10)   Car washes; and
      (11)   Others specified by the Director of Service or the Director of the
Ohio Environmental Protection Agency.
   (d)   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed at any point
of connection between the public potable or consumer's water system and an
auxiliary water supply, unless such auxiliary supply is accepted as an
additional source by the Director of Service and the source is approved by the
Ohio Environmental Protection Agency.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)
1048.09 TYPE OF PROTECTION REQUIRED.
   (a)   The type of protection required under Section
1048.08(b)(1), (2) and (3) shall depend on the degree of hazard which exists,
as follows:
      (1)   An approved air gap separation shall be installed where the public
potable water system may be contaminated with substances that could cause a
severe health hazard.
      (2)   An approved air gap separation or an approved reduced pressure
principle backflow prevention device shall be installed where the public
potable water system may be contaminated with a substance that could cause a
system or health hazard.
      (3)   An approved air gap separation or an approved reduced pressure
principle backflow prevention device or an approved double check valve assembly
shall be installed where the public potable water system may be polluted with
substances that could cause a pollution hazard not dangerous to health.
   (b)   The type of protection required under Section
1048.08(b)(4) shall be an approved air gap separation or an approved
interchangeable connection.
   (c)   Where an auxiliary water supply is used as a secondary source of water
for a fire protection system, the provisions of paragraph (a)(2) hereof for an
approved air gap separation or an approved interchangeable connection may not
be required, provided that:
      (1)   At premises where the auxiliary water supply may be contaminated
with substances that could cause a system or health hazard, the public or
consumer's potable water system shall be protected against backflow by
installation of an approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention
device.
      (2)   At all other premises, the public or consumer's potable water
system shall be protected against backflow by installation of either an
approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device or an approved
double check valve assembly.
      (3)   The public or consumer's potable water system shall be the primary
source of water for the fire protection system.
      (4)   The fire protection system shall be normally filled with water from
the public or consumer's potable water system.
      (5)   The water in the fire protection system shall be used for fire
protection only with no regular use of water from the fire protection system
downstream from the approved backflow prevention device.
      (6)   The water in the fire protection system shall contain no additives.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)
1048.10 SPECIFICATIONS FOR BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES.
   (a)   Any backflow prevention device required by this chapter shall be of a
model or construction approved by the Director of Service and the Director of
the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency and shall comply with the following:
      (1)   An air gap separation to be approved shall be at least twice the
diameter of the supply pipe, measured vertically above the top rim of the
vessel, but in no case less than one inch.
      (2)   A double check valve assembly or a reduced pressure principle
backflow prevention device shall be approved by the Director of Service and
shall appear on the current "list of approved backflow prevention devices" of
the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency.
      (3)   An interchangeable connection to be approved shall be either a
swing-type connector or a four-way valve of the lubricated plug-type that
operates through a mechanism which unseats the plugs, turns it ninety degrees
and reseats the plug. Four-way valves shall not be used as stop valves but must
have separate stop valves on each pipe connected to the valve. The tell-tale
port on the four-way valve shall have no piping connected and the threads or
flange on this port shall be destroyed so that a connection cannot be made.
   (b)   Existing backflow prevention devices approved by the Director of
Service or the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency at the time of installation
and properly maintained shall, except for inspection and maintenance
requirements, be excluded from the requirements of subsection (a) hereof,
provided that the Director of Service is assured that they will satisfactorily
protect the public potable water system. Whenever the existing device is moved
from the present location or requires more than minimum maintenance or when the
Director of Service finds that the maintenance of the device constitutes a
hazard to health, the device shall be replaced by a backflow prevention device
meeting the requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)
1048.11 INSTALLATION OF BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES.
   Backflow prevention devices required by this chapter shall be installed at a
location and in a manner approved by the Director of Service and shall be
installed by and at the expense of the water consumer. In addition, any
backflow prevention device required by Section
1048.08 shall be installed at a location and in a manner approved by the Ohio
Environmental Protection Agency as required by Ohio R. C. 6111.15.
   Backflow prevention devices installed on the service line to a consumer's
water system shall be located on the consumer's side of the water meter, as
close to the meter as is reasonably practical, and prior to any other
connection.
   Pits or vaults shall be of watertight construction, be so located and
constructed as to prevent flooding and shall be maintained free from standing
water by means of either a sump and pump or a suitable drain. Such sump pump or
drain shall not connect to a sanitary sewer nor permit flooding of the pit or
vault by reverse flow from its point of discharge. An access ladder and
adequate natural or artificial lighting shall be provided to permit maintenance
inspection and testing of the backflow prevention device.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)
1048.12 INSPECTION AND MAINTENANCE OF BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES.
   (a)   It shall be the duty of the consumer at any premises on which backflow
prevention devices required by this chapter are installed to have inspections,
tests and overhauls made in accordance with the following schedule or more
often where inspections indicate a need.
      (1)   Air separation shall be inspected at the time of installation and
at least every twelve months thereafter.
      (2)   Double check valve assemblies shall be inspected and tested for
tightness at the time of installation and at least every twelve months
thereafter. They shall be dismantled, inspected internally, cleaned and
repaired whenever needed and at least every thirty months.
      (3)   Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention devices shall be
inspected and tested for tightness at the time of installation and at least
every twelve months thereafter. They shall be dismantled, inspected internally,
cleaned and repaired whenever needed and at least every five years.
      (4)   Interchangeable connections shall be inspected at the time of
installation and at least every twelve months thereafter.
   (b)   Inspections, tests and overhauls of backflow prevention devices shall
be made at the expense of the water consumer and shall be performed by the
Director of Service or a person approved by the Director of Service as
qualified to inspect, test and overhaul backflow prevention devices.
   (c)   Whenever backflow prevention devices required by this chapter are
found to be defective, they shall be repaired or replaced at the expense of the
consumer without delay.
   (d)   The water consumer must maintain a complete record of each backflow
prevention device from the purchase to retirement. This includes a
comprehensive listing that includes a record of all tests, inspections and
repairs. Records of inspections, tests, repairs and overhauls shall be
submitted to the Director of Service.
   (e)   Backflow prevention devices shall not be bypassed, made inoperative,
removed or otherwise made ineffective without specific authorization by the
Director of Service.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)
1048.13 BOOSTER PUMPS.
   Where a booster pump has been installed on the service line to or within any
premises, such pump shall be equipped with a low pressure cut-off device
designed to shut off the booster pump when the pressure in the service line on
the suction side of the pump drops to ten pounds per square inch gage or less.
   It shall be the duty of the water consumer to maintain the low pressure cut-
off device in proper working order and to certify to the Director of Service,
at least once a year, that the device is operable.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)
1048.14 VIOLATIONS AND DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE.
   The Director of Service shall deny or discontinue, after reasonable notice
to the occupants thereof, the water service to any premises wherein any
backflow prevention device required by this chapter is not installed, tested
and maintained in a manner acceptable to the Director of Service or if it is
found that the backflow prevention device has been removed or bypassed, if an
unprotected cross-connection exists on the premises or if a low pressure cut-
off required by this chapter is not installed and maintained in working order.
   Water service to such premises shall not be restored until the consumer has
corrected or eliminated such conditions or defects in conformity with this
chapter and to the satisfaction of the Director of Service.
(Ord. 79-18. Passed 4-24-79.)

1052.01 REVENUE AND EXPENSES.
   All revenue derived from or obtained in the course of the operation of the
sewer system shall be placed to the credit of the Sewer Fund in the accounts of
the City from which the costs and expenses of the sewer system shall be paid
except as provided by Council from time to
time.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.02 NO GUARANTEE OF SERVICE.
   Because variable conditions may arise in the operation and maintenance of
the sewer system, the availability of sewer service to consumers is without
guarantee.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.03 DAMAGE OR OBSTRUCTION; UNAUTHORIZED CONNECTIONS.
   No person shall damage or obstruct the sewer system or make any connection
to or use the sewer system without first having received the permits required
to do so.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.04 UNAUTHORIZED SERVICE.
   No person shall permit another person to use the sewer system except as
provided in this chapter and sewer service shall not be resold by any person.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.05 SHUTOFF FOR MAINTENANCE OR REPAIR.
   Sewer service to consumers may be discontinued without notice if breaks in
sewer mains occur, pumping equipment breaks down, or construction,
reconstruction, repair, replacement, cleaning, extending or tapping of mains
requires, and no claims for damages of any nature whatsoever arising from such
action shall be paid.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.06 LINES UNDER CONSTRUCTION TO BE SEALED.
   All sewer lines and connection taps under construction shall be kept tightly
sealed to prevent surface or storm water from entering the sewer system.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.07 UNPOLLUTED WATER PROHIBITED.
   No person shall permit any surface or unpolluted ground water, subsurface
drainage, rain or storm water, water from condensers, water motors, heat
exchangers or cooling towers or unpolluted waste water from any source to enter
the sewer system.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.08 DAMAGING SUBSTANCES PROHIBITED; PRETREATMENT REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person shall permit any substance to enter the sewerage system
which would damage the sewer mains or which would be damaging to the efficient
operation of the sewage treatment plant.
   (b)   No person shall permit or cause any material, debris, petroleum
product, chemical or other substance to enter the storm or sanitary sewerage
system which could damage the system, affect or impede its flow or cause its
discharge to be polluted.
   (c)   Treatment of sewage to be discharged into the sewerage system to
remove all substances which would damage the sewer mains or which would be
damaging to the efficient operation of the sewage treatment plant shall be
performed by the consumer on whose premises such substances are mixed with
sewage to be discharged into the system.
(Ord. 81-08. Passed 2-10-81.)
1052.09 PROCESS OR COOLING WATER TO STORM DRAIN.
   Every consumer to whom over 100,000 gallons of water is delivered per
quarter year which is not polluted by its use on the consumer's premises shall
discharge such unpolluted water into the storm drain or, if no storm drain is
situated adjacent to the consumer's premises, into a storm water drainage
ditch.
   Every consumer discharging such unpolluted water as required by this section
shall, within thirty days of notice thereof given by the Superintendent of
Utilities, install a meter to separately register the amount of water
discharged into the storm sewer or storm water drainage ditch and shall make
such plumbing changes as are required by this section.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.10 CALCULATION OF CHARGE.
   The charge for sewer service provided in this chapter shall be based on the
quantity of water delivered to the consumer as evidenced by the consumer's
water meter or, if no such meter is used, by such other device or calculation
approved by the Director of Finance.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.11 CHARGES FOR SEWER SERVICE WITHIN THE CITY.
   (a)   Each consumer or owner whose premises within the City is connected to
the sewer system shall pay to the City for the connection and for sewer service
at the rate of not less than twenty-four dollars and twenty-eight cents
($24.28) bimonthly for each dwelling, commercial, manufacturing or other unit
served, plus four dollars and eighty-five cents ($4.85) per 1,000 gallons of
water delivered bimonthly over 5,000 gallons for each such unit served.
   (b)   Each consumer or owner whose premises within the City is connected to
the sewer system but not the water system shall pay to the City for the
connection and for sewer service at the flat rate of seventy-two dollars and
eighty-two cents ($72.82) bimonthly for each unit served.
(Ord. 98-22. Passed 12-22-98; Ord. 00-22. Passed 11-28-00; Ord. 01-30. Passed
12-11-01; Ord. 02-20. Passed 12-10-02; Ord. 04-27. Passed 12-14-04; Ord. 05-31.
Passed 11-22-05; Ord. 06-15. Passed 12-12-06; Ord. 07-14. Passed 11-27-07; Ord.
08-16. Passed 12-9-08; Ord. 09-14. Passed 12-8-09; Ord. 10-16. Passed 12-14-10;
Ord. 11-14. Passed 12-13-11; Ord. 12-12. Passed 11-13-12; Ord. 14-11. Passed
12-9-14; Ord. 15-16. Passed 10-27-15; Ord. 16-18. Passed 12-13-16; Ord. 17- 09.
Passed 11-14-17; Ord. 18-18. Passed 11-13-18; Ord. 19-19. Passed 11-12-19; Ord.
20-12. Passed 10-27-20; Ord. 22-02. Passed 1-11-22; Ord. 22-21. Passed 12-13-
22.)
1052.12 CHARGES FOR SEWER SERVICE OUTSIDE THE CITY.
   Each consumer or owner whose premises outside the City is connected to the
sewer system shall pay to the City for the connection and for sewer service at
the rate of not less than thirty-six dollars and forty-one cents ($36.41) bi-
monthly for each dwelling, commercial, manufacturing or other unit served, plus
seven dollars and twenty-eight cents ($7.28) per 1,000 gallons of water
delivered bimonthly over 5,000 gallons for each such unit served.
(Ord. 98-22. Passed 12-22-98; Ord. 00-22. Passed 11-28-00; Ord. 01-30. Passed
12-11-01; Ord. 02-20. Passed 12-10-02; Ord. 04-27. Passed 12-14-04; Ord. 05-31.
Passed 11-22-05; Ord. 06-15. Passed 12-12-06; Ord. 07-14. Passed 11-27-07; Ord.
08-16. Passed 12-9-08; Ord. 09-14. Passed 12-8-09; Ord. 10-16. Passed 12-14-10;
Ord. 11-14. Passed 12-13-11; Ord. 12-12. Passed 11-13-12; Ord. 14-11. Passed
12-9-14; Ord. 15-16. Passed 10-27-15; Ord. 16-18. Passed 12-13-16; Ord. 17- 09.
Passed 11-14-17; Ord. 18-18. Passed 11-13-18; Ord. 19-19. Passed 11-12-19; Ord.
20-12. Passed 10-27-20; Ord. 22-02. Passed 1-11-22; Ord. 22-21. Passed 12-13-
22.)
1052.13 CHARGES FOR DISCHARGING UNPOLLUTED WATER INTO STORM DRAINS.
   Each consumer or owner whose premises is connected to the storm drain or a
storm water drainage ditch, as required by Section
1052.09, shall pay to the City for the connection and storm drain or storm
water drainage ditch service at the rate of not less than three dollars and
forty-five cents ($3.45) bimonthly for each such connection, plus fifteen cents
($0.15) per 1,000 gallons of water delivered bimonthly in excess of 5,000
gallons for each such connection served. Such charges shall be credited and
deposited in the Street Construction Maintenance and Repair Fund.
(Ord. 78-01. Passed 1-10-78.)
1052.14 STATEMENTS; DELINQUENCIES; PENALTIES; DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE.
   Statements of the charges for sewer service shall be rendered bimonthly on
or about the twentieth day of the billing month for each consumer, as
determined by the Director of Finance, and the amount of all such charges shall
be paid to the City on or before ten days after the last day of the month in
which the statements are rendered. If the unpaid charges are not paid on or
before ten days after the last day of the month in which the statement was
rendered, an additional late payment charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00)
shall be added thereto and become part of such unpaid charges, and notice of
such additional charges shall be given in the manner provided for charges for
sewer service unless the late payment charge provided in Section
1044.13 has been added to the account. If the unpaid charges are not paid on or
before the last day of the month following the month in which the statements
were rendered, the water supply to the consumer so in default of payment shall
be disconnected by the City. Service restitution shall be made in accordance
with Section
1044.13. If the consumer of sewer service is not connected to the City water
supply, rendering the City incapable of discontinuing the water service as
provided for in Section
1044.13, the Director of Finance shall assess a late payment charge of twenty-
five dollars ($25.00) for each billing cycle late and a thirty-five dollar
($35.00) service fee to the account so in default of payment, and shall certify
such charges and fees to the County Auditor in accordance with Section
1040.17.
(Ord. 80-57. Passed 11-11-80; Ord. 06-15. Passed 12-12-06; Ord. 10-16. Passed
12-14-10; Ord. 19-07. Passed 6-25-19.)
1052.15 CONNECTION PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Before any connection is made for the use of the sewer system by a consumer,
the owner of the property to be served or the consumer shall apply to the
Department of Finance for a connection permit which, after the fees and charges
required herein have been paid to the City and the plans, information,
documents and assurances required herein have been submitted to the City, shall
be issued by the Director of Finance. The Division of Utilities shall, within a
reasonable time thereafter, make such connection in the manner provided herein.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.16 PERMIT APPLICATION INFORMATION.
   Applications for connection permits shall be made on a form required by the
Director of Finance and shall contain such information necessary to determine
the ownership, location, use or proposed use of the property to be served, the
amount of sewage likely to be discharged by the consumer, the location of the
building or other point of discharge on the property and such other
information, plans, documents and assurances required by the Director to
process the application.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.17 CONNECTION PERMIT FEES.
   The following shall be the schedule of fees for connections to the sanitary
sewer system.
   Before any person connects to or discharges sewage into the sewer system or
extends the use of the sanitary sewer system on his or her premises to
additional dwelling, commercial, manufacturing or other units, he or she shall
pay to the City a connection permit fee in an amount applicable to the schedule
below.
   (a)   Before any entity connects to, discharges into or extends the sanitary
sewer system for benefit of any tract of land or structures thereon, a
connection fee shall be paid to the City in an amount determined by the
applicable water tap/meter size required to serve the particular use.
Applicable fees shall be per the following schedule, but in no case less than
five hundred dollars (500.00).
Tap/Meter Size (in.)            Sewer Connection
                  Charge
5/8 x 3/4   $ 500.00
1 (single-family)    500.00
1 (all other)    850.00
1 1/2    1,800.00
2    2,700.00
3    5,100.00
4    8,500.00
6    17,000.00
8   27,000.00
   Connection fees for meter sizes not enumerated above shall be determined by
the City Engineer based upon accepted engineering standards for water use and
discharge, and in proportion to fees for given meter sizes. The City Manager
shall hear and decide appeals concerning fee determinations by the City
Engineer.
   (b)   For each addition to a use, requiring a separate water connection, an
additional sanitary sewer connection fee shall be charged according to the
schedule in subsection (a) hereof.
   (c)   Industrial or other users discharging excessive sewage shall be
charged an additional connection fee based on the excessive demand placed on
the system as determined by accepted engineering practices. If the sewage
discharged is determined by laboratory analysis to require additional
treatment, the City may charge a yearly fee equivalent to the cost of the
additional treatment agents or processes. If the sewage discharged is
determined by laboratory analysis or the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency
to be detrimental or incompatible with the wastewater treatment plant process,
the City may require preliminary treatment of the sewage before it is
discharged into the sanitary system.
   (d)   The purpose of the connection permit fees provided herein is to
provide funds necessary for construction, operation and maintenance of
wastewater treatment facilities.
(Ord. 77-13. Passed 5-10-77; Ord. 92-40. Passed 12-892; Ord. 98-17. Passed 11-
24-98.)
   (e)   A special tap-in fee shall be charged for each connection to sanitary
sewerage connected to, or served by, the sewage pumping station at 3640 West
National Road. In the case of single-family homes, the fee shall be one
thousand, five hundred dollars ($1,500) per home. In the case of attached
dwelling units, the fee shall be seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per
dwelling unit. In all other cases, the fee shall be two thousand dollars
($2,000), in addition to that provided for in subsection (a) hereof. The fees
provided for in this subsection may be revised from time to time, in the same
manner as other fees provided for in this section.
(Ord. 95-2. Passed 4-25-95.)
1052.18 INSPECTION BEFORE APPROVAL.
   The Department of Service shall inspect all sewer service connections and
lines and shall not approve the delivery of water to the premises unless the
sewer service connection and line have been installed in conformity with
approved standards for materials and workmanship. The fee for such inspection
shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per thirty-five linear feet or part thereof.
(Ord. 78-26. Passed 4-11-78.)
1052.19 EXTENSIONS UNDER PAVEMENT.
   No person shall extend sewer service lines under driveways, sidewalks or
other paved areas except for the shortest distance required.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.20 SERVICE AND PRIVILEGES AUTHORIZED BY CONNECTION PERMIT.
   An approved connection permit authorizes a property owner or consumer to
connect to and discharge sewage into the sewer system as permitted in this
chapter and as restricted by the City from time to time and in a like manner
and with the same privileges as other property owners and consumers connected
to the sewer system. The City will tap the sewer main serving the property
owner's or consumer's premises.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.21 RESPONSIBILITIES OF PROPERTY OWNER OR CONSUMER.
   The property owner or consumer shall be responsible for all costs of
materials and work necessary to install a sewer service line and appurtenances
in accordance with the Montgomery County Uniform Building Code, as adopted in
Chapter 1420 of Part Fourteen - the Building and Housing Code, which shall
begin at the sewer main serving the premises and continue to or onto the
property served or point of use.
   The property owner or consumer shall expose the sewer main at the point to
be tapped.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.22 UNAUTHORIZED TAPS.
   No person shall make any tap or connection except as authorized by the
Superintendent of Utilities.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71
1052.23 PEAK DEMAND FLOW.
   The sewer service connection and sewer service line to the premises to be
served shall be of sufficient size as determined by accepted engineering
practice to accept the flow of sewage discharged into the sewer service line by
the consumer at peak demand, and in no case less than four inches nominal
diameter.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.24 SEPARATE CONNECTIONS REQUIRED.
   Each separate lot, parcel or tract of land shall be connected to the sewer
system separately and charges for sewer service to each shall be individually
computed.
(Ord. 71-51. Passed 10-19-71.)
1052.25 PRIVIES, CESSPOOLS, PRIVATE SEWERS PROHIBITED IF PUBLIC AVAILABLE.
   No owner, agent, lessee, tenant or occupant of any lot or land located
within the City shall establish, construct, maintain or permit to remain a
privy, cesspool or other receptacle for sewage or excreta, or a connection to a
private sewer, ditch or other outlet, if such lot or land is accessible to a
public sewer constructed and used for the purpose of conveying sewage, and if a
public water main or other water supply satisfactory to permit use of plumbing
is available. When such public sewer and water mains or other water supply are
available or are hereafter made available, a connection to such public sewer
shall be established and used by such owner, agent, lessee, tenant or occupant.
(Ord. 96. Passed 3-5-40.)
1052.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than sixty
days, or both, for each offense. Except where otherwise provided, a separate
offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.
