1070.01 AUTHORITY; PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to improve, operate and protect parks,
parkways, forests, detention and retention basins and other public open space
areas lying within or outside of the City, as provided in Section
240.06.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Animal" means a quadruped, bird, fish, reptile, amphibian or insect.
   (b)   "City" means the City of Englewood, Montgomery County, Ohio.
   (c)   "City Manager" means the City Manager of Englewood or his or her
designee. (d) "Fish" and "fishing" mean taking or attempting to take fish by
any method, and all other acts of placing, setting, drawing or using any device
commonly used to take fish, whether resulting in such taking or not.
   (e)   "Motor vehicle" means any vehicle propelled or drawn by power other
than muscular power.
   (f)   "Motorboat" means a watercraft propelled by a mechanical device,
electric motor or internal combustion engine.
   (g)   "Park" means any land or water area owned, leased or otherwise
controlled by the City.
   (h)   "Park waters" means a lake, pond, reservoir, stream, channel, lagoon
or other body of water, or any part thereof, whether natural or artificial,
located in or adjoining a park.
   (i)   "Person" means an individual, company, partnership, corporation,
association or combination of individuals, or an employee, agent or officer
thereof.
   (j)   "Police officer" means a sworn officer of the Department of Police and
every other law enforcement officer of the State or of any political
subdivision thereof, including, but not limited to, State highway patrolmen,
sheriffs, deputy sheriffs, constables, conservancy district employees qualified
under Ohio R. C. 2901.01 and Division of Wildlife game protectors.
   (k)   "Vehicle" means anything on wheels.
   (1)   ' Watercraft" means any vessel designed for navigation on water,
including, but not limited to, a rowboat, sailboat or motorboat.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.03 REMOVAL OR DESTRUCTION OF PROPERTY.
   No person in a park shall:
   (a)   Remove any property, or part thereof, which is owned, leased or
otherwise controlled by the City, without first obtaining a permit therefor
from the City Manager;
   (b)   Remove any property, or part thereof, which is owned, leased or
otherwise controlled by the City, from its location, without first obtaining
permission therefor from a City employee;
   (c)   Write upon, cut, mutilate, deface or damage in any manner any
building, equipment or other property, or part thereof, which is owned, leased
or otherwise controlled by the City;
   (d)   Dig, move or carry away any rock, stone, sod, sand, earth, tree, wood,
shrub, plant, flower, nut or other seed without first obtaining a permit
therefor from the Manager; or
   (e)   Trample upon, injure, destroy, break, cut, chop or deface in any
manner any stone, tree, shrub, plant or flower.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.04 DEPOSIT OF WASTE MATERIALS; POLLUTION OF WATERS.
   (a)   No person in a park shall deposit or discard, or cause to be deposited
or discarded, intentionally or unintentionally, any paper, garbage, ashes,
refuse or other noxious or waste material, other than in receptacles provided
for the disposal of such materials.
   (b)   No person shall deposit or discard or cause to be deposited or
discarded, intentionally or unintentionally, adjacent to a park, any paper,
garbage, ashes, refuse or other noxious or waste material which may blow, wash
or be transported by any other means into a park.
   (c)   No person in a park shall discharge, throw, drop or cause to flow into
park waters any noxious or deleterious substance, either solid or liquid, which
renders such waters harmful or inimical to the public health or to animal life.
   (d)   No person shall discharge, throw, drop or cause to flow into waters
adjacent to a park any noxious or deleterious substance, either solid or
liquid, which renders park waters harmful or inimical to the public health or
to animal life.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.05 PROTECTION OF ANIMALS; HUNTING AND FISHING.
   No person in a park shall:
   (a)   Hunt, trap or in any other way abuse, molest, injure, pursue or
destroy an animal;
   (b)   Move, injure or destroy a bird nest, egg or animal habitation;
   (c)   Fish in park waters in a manner or at a time prohibited by Ohio R. C.
Chapter 1533, as now in effect or as hereafter amended;
   (d)   Fish in park waters without a license therefor from the State if such
license is required by Ohio R. C. 1533.32 through 1533. as now in effect or as
here after amended;
   (e)   Fish in park waters in violation of any sign prohibiting fishing or a
manner thereof;
   (f)   Fish in park waters where a fee for such fishing is charged by the
City, or for a license therefor, without paying such fee;
   (g)   Have in his or her possession an animal unless the animal is
controlled by a lead or bridle or unless the animal is kept in a vehicle or
suitably caged; (h) Abandon an animal;
   (i)   Hunt or fish with a bow and arrow except in areas designated therefor
by the City and so posted;
   (j)   Have in his or her possession or shoot a crossbow; or
   (k)   Herd, graze, drive or permit to run at large within a park any bovine,
horse, mule, donkey, goat, swine, sheep or other animal or poultry or other
fowl.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.06 PEACE DISTURBANCES; GAMBLING; SEX OFFENSES; ALCOHOL AND OTHER DRUGS.
   (a)   No person shall be permitted to remain in a park for no other apparent
purpose than to loiter or consume idle time. At the discretion of a police
officer, such occupants may be required to leave. Offenders will be prosecuted.
   (b)   No person in or adjacent to a park shall conduct himself or herself,
by word or by act, in a riotous, disorderly, boisterous or other manner so as
to disturb the peace and good order of the park.
   (c)   No person in or adjacent to a park shall operate or play a radio,
television, musical instrument or amplifying or sound equipment so as to
disturb the peace and good order of the park.
   (d)   No person in a park shall solicit or procure participants for, engage
in or promote a game which is played for money or some other thing of value.
   (e)   No person in a park shall use insulting, abusive, threatening, profane
or indecent language.
   (f)   No person in a park shall loiter in the vicinity of a toilet or enter
toilet facilities provided for the exclusive use of the opposite sex.
   (g)   No person in a park shall resist, obstruct or abuse a police officer
who is engaged in the lawful execution of his or her duties.
   (h)   No person in a park shall willfully assault or commit bodily injury
upon another or engage in or abet or aid in a fight, quarrel or other
disturbance.
   (i)   No person shall assemble with others in or adjacent to a park for an
unlawful purpose, in riotous assemblage or with intent to annoy, harass or
inflict property damage or bodily injury upon another person or inflict damage
to the park.
   (j)   No person in a park, except a police officer, shall have in his or her
possession any switchblade, hunting knife, dagger, metal knuckles, slingshot or
other dangerous weapon.
   (k)   No person in a park shall solicit or attempt to solicit another to
engage in an act of sex perversion or solicit or request another to commit,
perform or engage in any lewd, lascivious, obscene or indecent act or behavior.
   (l)   No person in a park shall appear in a state of nudity, or in attire
normally worn only by the opposite sex, or make any indecent exposure of his or
her person.
   (m)   No person in a park shall consume or have in his or her possession or
in his or her vehicle any alcoholic beverage or intoxicating liquor. Beer,
liquor, wine or any other alcoholic beverage or intoxicating liquor may be
confiscated by a police officer.
   (n)   No person in a park shall sell or offer for sale any alcoholic
beverage or intoxicating liquor.
   (o)   No person in a park shall be intoxicated or under the influence of any
alcoholic beverage or intoxicating liquor.
   (p)   No person in a park shall possess, sell or offer for sale any type of
narcotic drug, opiate or hallucinogen, or any equipment for administering such
drugs, opiates or hallucinogens. Any narcotic drug, opiate or hallucinogen may
be confiscated by a police officer.
   (q)   No person in a park shall smoke, drink, have injected or inject into
himself or herself or otherwise use any type of narcotic drug, opiate or
hallucinogen.
   (r)   No person in a park shall be under the influence of any type of
narcotic, drug, opiate or hallucinogen.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
   (s)   Subsections (m), (n) and (o) hereof may be suspended when authorized
by the issuance of a permit according to
Chapter 1072.
(Ord. 82-24. Passed 10-26-82.)
1070.07 FIRES.
   No person in a park shall:
   (a)   Start or maintain a fire except in a place or at a site designated for
such purpose;
   (b)    Collect wood for the purpose of building a fire;
   (c)   Place portable stoves or grills in shelters or on combustible picnic
tables;
   (d)   Deposit burning material or hot ashes on grass or plants or in refuse
receptacles; or
   (e)   Build a fire at a time or period when the City Manager has prohibited
the building of fires.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.08 CAMPING.
   (a)   No person in a park shall camp in an area or on a site which is not
designated for such purpose by the City Manager.
   (b)   No person shall establish or maintain a camp or other temporary
lodging or sleeping place in a park without first obtaining a permit therefor
from the Manager.
   (c)   No group shall camp in a park without first obtaining a permit
therefor from the Manager.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.09 FIREARMS AND OTHER WEAPONS.
   (a)   No person in a park shall carry on or about his or her person any bow
and arrow, air or gas gun, missile, or sling shot or other missile throwing
device; provided, however that bows and arrows may be carried in areas
designated by the Manager for archery purposes.
   (b)   No person shall discharge in a park, or into a park, any firearm, bow
and arrow, air or gas gun, missile, or sling shot or other missile throwing
device; provided, however, that bows and arrows may be used in areas designated
by the Manager for archery purposes.
   (c)   No person in a park shall carry on or about his or her person any axe,
hatchet, or saw, for the purposes of a deadly weapon; or any dangerous ordnance
as that term is defined in R.C. § 2923.11 (K).
   (d)   No person in a park shall carry on or about his or her person any
explosive device as that term is defined in R.C. § 2923.11 (H), or any
incendiary device as that term is defined in R.C. § 2923.11(1).
   (e)    The term "firearm" as used in this section shall have the same
meaning as the definition of that term in R.C. § 2923.11 (B).
   (f)   The prohibition in subsection (b) of this section against the
discharge of any firearm in a park or into a park does not apply when a firearm
is discharged in self-defense, in defense of others, or by a police officer in
the discharge of official duty.
(Ord. 22-13. Passed 9-27-22.)
1070.10 PEDDLING AND SOLICITING; SIGNS.
   No person in a park shall:
   (a)   Sell or offer for sale any article, privilege or service, unless such
sale or offer is pursuant to a contract with the City Manager;
   (b)   Beg, peddle or solicit for money, a privilege or a service; or
   (c)   Erect a sign on, or attach a sign to, property owned or controlled by
the Manager, or display any placard, notice, advertisement, circular, banner or
statement, other than a permanent sign, on a vehicle.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.11 HORSES.
   (a)   No person shall ride a horse in a park except in areas or on trails
designated for such use.
   (b)   No person shall ride a horse in a park in such a manner as to endanger
the rider or any other person, the horse or any property.
   (c)   No person shall ride a horse in a park when it is closed without first
obtaining a permit therefor from the City Manager.
   (d)   Horseback riders in a park shall yield the right of way to pedestrians
and motorists at points where bridle trails intersect foot trails, roads,
drives and parkways.
   (e)   No person shall leave a horse unattended in a park other than for the
purpose of stabling the horse at a designated stable.
   (f)   No person shall over-ride, cruelly mistreat, mutilate or torture a
horse in a park.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.12 HOURS; USE OF PARKS DURING EMERGENCIES. No person shall:
   (a)   Enter a park except during the hours posted;
   (b)   Enter a park or remain in a park during the hours the park is closed
without first obtaining a permit therefor from the City Manager; or
   (c)   Enter a park during a period of emergency so declared by the Manager.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.13 FIREWORKS AND EXPLOSIVES.
   No person in a park shall:
   (a)   Have in his or her possession or ignite any fireworks; or
   (b)   Have in his or her possession or detonate any explosive without first
obtaining a permit therefor from the City Manager.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.14 OPERATION OF VEHICLES; PARKING.
   (a)   Driving in Permitted Areas. No person shall operate a vehicle in a
park except on and within the paths and roads provided for such vehicle.
   (b)   Reckless Operation. No person shall operate a vehicle in a park in
such a manner as to endanger the operator thereof or any other person or
property.
   (c)   Barricades. No person shall drive around, cause to be moved or damage
any barricade or barrier placed in a park to temporarily or permanently close a
road to traffic.
   (d)   Speed. No person shall operate a vehicle in a park in excess of ten
miles per hour.
   (e)   Parking. No person shall park a vehicle in a park, except in places
designated for such purpose.
   (f)   After-Hours Parking. No person shall leave a vehicle in a park during
the hours when the park is closed. After two hours, a vehicle so left is
subject to tow at the owner's expense.
   (g)   One-Way Roads. No person shall drive a vehicle in a park on a road or
path in a direction other than that indicated by traffic signs.
   (h)   Trucks. No person shall drive a truck, tractor or other vehicle, which
is at that time used for the transportation of goods or materials, over a park
road without first obtaining a permit therefor from the City Manager.
   (i)   Safety and Load Limits. No person shall operate a vehicle in a park
when such vehicle fails to comply with the equipment and load restrictions
contained in Ohio R. C. 4513.01 through 4513.34, as now in effect or hereafter
amended.
   (j)   Impounding Vehicles. A vehicle in a park in violation of any of the
provisions of this section shall be removed or caused to be removed by a police
officer to a location in or outside of a park, where the same may be kept until
the owners or their authorized representatives obtain an order from the Police
Department releasing such vehicles to the owners thereof or their authorized
representatives.
   (k)   Licensed Drivers. No person shall drive a motor vehicle in a park
unless such person is licensed as an operator or chauffeur.
   (1)   Registered Vehicles. No person shall drive a motor vehicle in a park
unless such motor vehicle has been registered as provided in Ohio R. C.
Chapters 4501 and 4503, as now in effect or hereafter amended.
   (m)   Alcoholic Beverages. No person shall consume any beer or intoxicating
liquor in a park while driving or parking in a motor vehicle.
   (n)   "Peeling." No person shall intentionally accelerate a motor vehicle in
a park causing the rubber tires to mark or deface park roadway surfaces.
   (o)   Motorized Bicycles; Motorcycles. Mopeds, motor bikes and motorcycles
shall not be operated or parked in a park in areas designated off-limits to
motor vehicles.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
   1070.15 MODEL AIRPLANES AND OTHER NOISE-MAKING DEVICES; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person in or adjacent to a park shall operate any engine-powered model or
toy airplane, boat, car, siren or any other noise-making device without first
obtaining a permit therefor from the City Manager.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.16 SNOWMOBILES AND ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES; WATER SPORTS.
   No person in a park shall:
   (a)   Operate a snowmobile, all-terrain vehicle or hovercraft;
   (b)   Swim or wade in any park waters without first obtaining a permit
therefor from the City Manager; or
   (c)   Ice skate or be found upon frozen water unless it is posted as being
safe for such purposes.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.17 EXEMPTION OF EMPLOYEES; AUTHORITY OF DESIGNATED EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   Acts of employees of the City, to the extent necessary for the
performance of their authorized duties, shall be exempt from this chapter.
   (b)   The City Manager may, from time to time, designate a City employee to
exercise any authority permitted him or her pursuant to this chapter.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.18 WARD FIELD PARK.
   (a)   The official hours of operation of Ward Field Park are 9:00 a. m. to
dusk.
   (b)   Upon application therefor to the City Manager, special permission in
the form of a written permit may be granted for seasonal extension of the
evening hours, but in no case shall Ward Field remain open past 11:00 p. m.
   (c)   The Englewood Hills Little League Association will not begin an inning
later than 10:00 p. m. or vacate the premises later than 11:00 p. m. , as
specified in subsection (b) hereof.
   (d)   The Manager is hereby authorized and directed to erect a padlocked
entrance gate at Ward Field Park, such gate and any other necessary traffic
control devices to be utilized for access control.
   (e)   The Manager is hereby authorized and directed to clearly post the
hours of operation and strictly enforce such limitations.
   (f)   The overall expense, maintenance and management of resources at Ward
Field Park shall predominantly rest with the Association, until such time as
Council may decide otherwise. Such policy shall not be interpreted to preclude
the general public from making use of the Park for other than organized
activities.
   (g)   In recognition of the maintenance responsibility mentioned in
subsection (f) hereof, the Association shall be permitted to operate a
concession stand and retain the full profits thereof.
   (h)   Any substantial improvement to the property shall be authorized in
writing by the Manager or his or her designee and shall conform to the Ward
Field Park Master Plan.
(Res. 67-80. Passed 8-12-80.)
1070.19 VIOLATION; EJECTION FROM PARK.
   Police officers may order any person violating any of the provisions of this
chapter to leave a park, and no person shall fail to obey such an order.
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
1070.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not more than one. hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first
offense. For each subsequent offense, such person shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00).
(Ord. 80-42. Passed 9-9-80.)
CHAPTER 1072
Public Meeting Facilities
1072.01   Purpose.
1072.02   Definitions.
1072.03   Removal or destruction of property.
1072.04   Policies for use of facilities.
1072.05   Alcoholic beverages.
1072.06   Violations; forfeiture of deposits.
 
1072.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Public meetings - see ADM.
Ch. 206
   Disturbing lawful meetings - see GEN. OFF.
648.05
   Unlawful congregations - see GEN. OFF.
648.09
   Disturbances in public facilities - see S. U. & P. S.
1070.06
   Smoking in public facilities and vehicles - see GEN. OFF.
660.175
1072.01 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to improve, operate and protect public
meeting facilities owned by the City.
(Ord. 82-5. Passed 1-12-82.)
1072.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "City" means the City of Englewood.
   (b)   "Department of Police" means the City Department of Police or any
other public police agency authorized to enforce the law in the City.
   (c)   "Manager" means the City Manager or his or her designee.
(Ord. 82-5. Passed 1-12-82.)
   (d)   "Public meeting facility" means an enclosed structure and/or other
public property owned or administered by the City which is made available to
individuals, groups and/or organizations for meetings or gatherings, including
the Englewood Government Center, the Community Center, parklands, rights of way
and similar public areas.
(Ord. 82-24. Passed 10-26-82.)
1072.03 REMOVAL OR DESTRUCTION OF PROPERTY.
   No person in a public meeting facility shall:
   (a)   Remove any property or part thereof which is owned, leased or
otherwise controlled by the City, without first obtaining a permit therefor
from the City Manager; or
   (b)   Write upon, cut, mutilate, deface or damage in any manner any
building, equipment or other property, or part thereof, which is owned, leased
or otherwise controlled by the City.
(Ord. 82-5. Passed 1-12-82.)
1072.04 POLICIES FOR USE OF FACILITIES.
   Policies for the use of public meeting facilities, including those effective
upon adoption of this chapter, shall, from time to time, be established and
revised in conformity with this chapter.
(Ord. 82-5. Passed 1-12-82.)
1072.05 ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.
   (a)   No person shall sell or consume or permit the sale or consumption of
any alcoholic beverage within a public meeting facility, except as approved by
the issuance of a permit therefor, and in compliance with certain regulations,
as provided or referenced in this chapter.
   (b)   A permit for the consumption of alcoholic beverages in a public
meeting facility may be issued by the City to persons who comply with all
applicable rules, ordinances and State statutes and upon payment of a fifty
dollar ($50.00) cash deposit to the Department of Finance. Such deposit or any
portion thereof shall be forfeited to the City if, in the sole judgment of the
City Manager, 'persons using the facilities under such permit do any of the
following:
      (1)   Cause or allow damage or theft of City property;
      (2)   Cause or allow such conduct of drunkenness, disorderliness or
disturbance as necessitates the involvement of the Department of Police; or
      (3)   Fail to honor assurances made as prerequisite to obtaining a
permit.
   (c)   A permit may be issued which allows the sale of alcoholic beverages in
a public meeting facility, as well as consumption, subject to subsection (b)
hereof, provided that a person seeking such permit first complies with all
requirements of the State Department of Liquor Control and presents proof of
such compliance to the Director of Police as a prerequisite to the issuance of
such a permit.
   (d)   No alcoholic beverage shall be carried or transported in any way upon
or across the premises of a public meeting facility, except within rooms
specifically designated by the City, unless such alcoholic beverage is in a
closed container.
   (e)   Permission to sell and/or consume alcoholic beverages in public
meeting facilities shall be granted only if the consumption of alcoholic
beverages is incidental to and not a primary purpose of a proposed gathering.
No permit shall be issued for the primary purpose of generating revenue from
the sale of alcoholic beverages.
(Ord. 82-5. Passed 1-12-82.)
1072.06 VIOLATIONS; FORFEITURE OF DEPOSITS.
   Any person found guilty of a State or local law while using a public meeting
facility may, in addition to any other penalty, be deemed to have forfeited any
deposit made for the use of such facility and may be prohibited from future use
of such facility.
(Ord. 82-5. Passed 1-12-82.)
1072.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 1074
Alarm Systems
1074.01   Purpose and scope.
1074.02   Definitions.
1074.03   False alarms.
1074.04   Emergency building and site access; key lock systems.
1074.05   Nonliability of City.
1074.06   Separability.
 
1074.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Theft alarms - see TRAF.
438.20
   Making false alarms - see GEN. OFF.
648.08
1074.01 PURPOSE AND SCOPE.
   (a)   The purpose of this chapter is to protect the emergency services of
the Police and Fire Departments of the City of Englewood from misuse, by
responding to defective alarm systems, excessive false alarms and nuisance 9-1-
1 telephone calls. This chapter also provides for quick access into buildings
and/or facilities by providing a common key box/key switch program.
   (b)   This chapter governs alarm systems, gated communities, alarm users,
telephone subscribers with access to emergency 9-1-1 services and businesses
that provide on-premises public pay telephone services. It provides for
penalties for violations and penalties for excessive false alarms.
(Ord. 00-19. Passed 9-26-00.)
1074.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Alarm System" means any assembly of equipment, mechanical or
electrical, arranged to signal the occurrence of an unauthorized entry, robbery
or other criminal offense, fire emergency or medical emergency. For the
purposes this chapter, "alarm system" includes the 9-1-1 telephone system and
equipment. Alarm systems specifically exclude those installed on motor
vehicles.
   (b)   "Alarm user" means a person or entity of any kind who or which is:
      (1)   An owner (or lessee) and also the user of an alarm system, as the
occupant of the premises where the system is installed (the premises);
      (2)   The owner (or lessee) of such a premises which is occupied by
another person or entity, if there is no written contract stating that the
occupant is to be responsible for the alarm system;
      (3)   The occupant of such a premises, if there is a written agreement
that the occupant is responsible for the alarm system;
      (4)   The subscriber or user of telephone services that access the 9-1-
1 emergency telephone system and the manager or owner of a business that
provides "on premises" public pay telephones.
   (c)   "False alarm" means the activation of an alarm system or emergency 9-
1-1 telephone system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper
installation or the negligence of the owner, lessee or subscriber of an alarm
system or any of his or her employees, family members, guests or agents. "False
alarm" includes nuisance 9-1-1 phone calls whether initiated by equipment
failure or human negligence, that results in a police, fire or EMS response.
Nuisance 9-1-1 calls include those 9-1-1 calls intentionally generated wherein
no police or fire emergency exists and the caller was aware no actual emergency
existed at the time the call was placed.
   (d)   "Key box" means a commercially available secure container openable by
a secure and common key carried by the Fire and/or Police Department. The key
box is to be supplied by the building owner and is to be provided with a
building key for use by emergency services to access alarm systems and the bulk
of the interior of the building. Key boxes must match current boxes in use in
the community.
   (e)   "Key switch" means a commercially available secure electric switch
openable by a secure and common key carried by the Fire and/or Police
Department. The key switch is to be supplied by the building owner and operates
electric doors or gates for use by emergency services to access alarm systems
and the bulk of the interior of the building or complex. Key switches must
match current switches in use in the community.
   (f)   "Gated community" means a grouping of multiple or single commercial
and/or residential units accessible through locked gates. Emergency services
need quick access to these structures to provided requested services.
(Ord. 00-19. Passed 9-26-00.)
1074.03 FALSE ALARMS.
   (a)   If more than three false fire or medic alarms are produced by any
alarm system in a twelve-month period, a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
shall be assessed on the alarm user for the fourth false alarm, and two hundred
dollars ($200.00) shall be assessed for each successive false alarm thereafter.
   (b)   If more than ten false police alarms are produced by any alarm system
in a twelve-month period, a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be
assessed on the alarm user for the eleventh false alarm, and two hundred
dollars ($200.00) shall be assessed for each successive false alarm thereafter.
(Ord. 00-19. Passed 9-26-00.)
1074.04 EMERGENCY BUILDING AND SITE ACCESS; KEY LOCK SYSTEMS.
   (a)   All buildings equipped with automatic fire alarm systems shall provide
emergency building access. The alarm user will provide, at their costs, a key
box or key switch. These shall be located pursuant to Fire Department
direction. The alarm user shall provide a key for the key box that accesses the
alarm and/or fire protection system controls as well as the bulk of the
building. Buildings occupied and open to the public twenty-four hours per day,
365 days per year, and staffed by capable employees of the alarm user who are
equipped with proper key access to the building, shall be exempt from the key
box/key switch requirement.
   (b)   All buildings or complexes equipped with perimeter fencing shall
provide at the owner's cost, a key box (with key) or key switch that provides
access through a gate or gates as directed by the Fire Department. All private,
gated communities of a commercial and/or residential nature shall be included
in this requirement.
(Ord. 00-19. Passed 9-26-00.)
1074.05 NONLIABILITY OF CITY.
   The City of Englewood shall not be liable for any failure or neglect to
respond appropriately upon receipt of an alarm from such a device or phone call
from the emergency 9-1-1 system, nor for the failure of the transmission of
alarm signals and pre-recorded alarm messages, or the relaying of such signals
and messages .
(Ord. 00-19. Passed 9-26-00.)
1074.06 SEPARABILITY.
   If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter is
for any reason held to be unconstitutional by the decision of any court of
competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the
remaining portions of this chapter. The City Council hereby declares that it
would have passed this chapter, and each section, subsection, sentence, clause
and phrase hereof, irrespective of the fact that any one or more of the
sections, subsections, sentences, clauses or phrases might be declared invalid.
(Ord. 00-19. Passed 9-26-00.)
1074.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Failure or omission to comply with any section or provision of this
chapter shall be deemed a violation. Each day such a failure or omission
continues to exist after a written notice of that failure or omission is mailed
or otherwise delivered to the last known address of the alarm user or to the
address at which the alarm system is located shall constitute a separate
violation.
   (b)   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized to place such unpaid
amount on the property tax duplicate if such penalty remains unpaid beyond
thirty days.
(Ord. 00-19. Passed 9-26-00.)

CHAPTER 1220
Planning Commission (Administrative Board for Planning and Zoning Appeals)
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
3.09 of the City Charter, which created the Planning Commission, was repealed
by the voters on November 4, 1980. The functions of the Commission are now
performed by the Administrative Board for Planning and Zoning Appeals.
1220.01   Establishment; general duties. (Repealed)
1220.02   Specific powers and duties; rules and regulations.
1220.03   Membership; terms; compensation; removal. (Repealed in part)
1220.04   Officers; duties.
1220.05   Election and terms of officers.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   City planning commissions - see Ohio R.C. 713.01 et seq.
   Approval of plats - see Ohio R.C. 711.09; P. & Z.
1242.02
   Authority re Zoning Code - see P. & Z.
1268.03
1220.01 ESTABLISHMENT; GENERAL DUTIES. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: This section was repealed by implication by the amendment of
Section 3.09 of the City Charter.)
1220.02 SPECIFIC POWERS AND DUTIES; RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (a)   The Planning Commission (Administration Board for Planning and Zoning
Appeals) shall have such powers and perform such duties as are provided in the
Zoning Code.
   (b)   The Commission shall perform such duties and have such powers as are
provided in the Subdivision Regulations.
   (c)   The Commission shall perform such duties and have such powers as are
provided in
Chapter 1280 (Signs).
   (d)   The Commission shall review, evaluate and make such recommendations to
Council concerning the physical, environmental, social, economic and
governmental characteristics, functions, services and other aspects of
development affecting the City. The Commission may make special maps and
studies whenever necessary to promote better understanding and administration
of its functions or other planning or development matters.
   (e)   The Commission shall adopt its own rules of procedure not inconsistent
with law.
   (f)   The Commission may adopt such regulations not inconsistent with law
necessary for the proper and efficient administration of its functions.
(Ord. 73-30. Passed 9-11-73. )
1220.03 MEMBERSHIP; TERMS; COMPENSATION; REMOVAL. (REPEALED IN PART)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Part of this section, as enacted by Ordinance 73-30, passed
September 11, 1973, was repealed by implication by the amendment of Section 3.
09 of the City Charter.)
   Members of the Planning Commission (Administrative Board for Planning and
Zoning Appeals) shall serve without compensation but their reasonable expenses
shall be paid by the City. The Manager shall be an ex-officio member of the
Commission without a vote but he or she may discuss with or advise the
Commission on any business or related matters before it. Members may be removed
by Council for just cause, including, but not limited to, excessive unexcused
absences from Commission meetings.
(Ord. 73-30. Passed 9-11-73.)
1220.04 OFFICERS; DUTIES.
   (a)   The officers of the Planning Commission (Administrative Board for
Planning and Zoning Appeals) shall consist of a President, a Vice-President and
a Secretary. In accordance with the Commission's rules, the President shall
preside at meetings, call special meetings and decide all points of order; the
Vice-President shall perform the duties of the President in his or her absence
and shall succeed to a vacant office of the President. In such event, a Vice-
President shall be elected at the next regular Commission meeting. Vacancies in
the offices of Vice-President and Secretary shall be filled in a like manner.
The Secretary shall keep all records, minutes and actions of the Commission,
conduct correspondence and give required notices.
   (b)   A Recording Secretary shall be appointed by the City Manager, with the
approval of the Commission, to record the business of the Commission. Minutes
shall be presented to the Commission for approval. The Recording Secretary may
be authorized by the Secretary to advertise public hearings and to send
required notices.
(Ord. 73-30. Passed 9-11-73.)
1220.05 ELECTION AND TERMS OF OFFICERS.
   Regular elections for officers and installation of new members shall be at
the annual meeting of the Planning Commission (Administrative Board for
Planning and Zoning Appeals) which shall be held at the first regular meeting
following the first day of January of each year. Officers shall be elected to
serve one-year terms but may be re-elected. Voting shall be by recorded roll-
call votes.
(Ord. 73-30. Passed 9-11-73.)
CHAPTER 1222
Erosion and Sedimentation Control
1222.01   Findings.

   CROSS REFERENCES
   Polluting and diverting watercourses - see GEN. OFF.

   Lot drainage - see GEN. OFF.
660.11
   Preservation of physical and cultural features of land - see P. & Z.
1248.02
   Storm drainage in subdivisions - see P. & Z.
1250.06
   Landscaping and tree cover; street trees in subdivisions - see P. & Z.
1250.10
1222.01 FINDINGS.
   Council hereby finds that the lands and waters of the City are natural
assets and resources and that such lands are being despoiled and such waters
are being polluted as the result of erosion and deposit of sediment arising
from disturbances and changes of the surface of such lands.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72. )
1222.02 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to promote the public safety, health,
convenience and general welfare and to protect property, lands and waters
within the City, to the extent practical, by alleviating harmful and damaging
effects of on-site erosion, siltation on neighboring downhill and downstream
properties and pollution of streams and bodies of water during and after
development, through adequate controls of erosion and sedimentation of both a
temporary and permanent nature. Such controls shall be provided by the property
owner during all phases of any clearing, stripping, excavating, filling,
grading, construction or other activity involving the disturbance of natural
terrain or vegetative ground cover.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72.)
1222.03 APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   All public and private development of areas for nonagricultural uses, such
as housing, commercial, industrial and recreational development, roads and
utility services, shall comply with this chapter, except as exempted by Section
1222-05.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72.)
1222.04 GRADING PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Except as exempted by Section
1222.05, no person shall do any clearing, stripping, excavating, filling,
grading, construction or other activity involving the disturbance of natural
terrain or vegetative ground cover unless he or she has a valid grading permit
therefor issued by the City Engineer.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72.)
1222.05 EXCEPTIONS.
   A grading permit will not be required under the following conditions:
   (a)   For the construction of a single-family or two-family structure which
is located on a lot within a plat that has received final approval in
accordance with the Subdivision Regulations, provided, however, that erosion
and sedimentation control measures have been and are being employed in
accordance with the approved grading, drainage, erosion and sedimentation
control plans and specifications for the plat;
   (b)   For activity pursuant to a permit issued by the Director of Service in
accordance with Section
1020.01 for work in streets or rights of way dedicated to public use, provided,
however, that erosion and sedimentation control measures as approved by the
City Engineer have been and are being employed;
   (c)   For authorized City capital improvement and public works projects,
provided, however, that erosion and sedimentation control measures as approved
by the City Engineer have been and are being employed;
   (d)   For accepted agricultural land management practices, such as plowing
and construction of agricultural structures and nursery operations such as the
removal and/or transplanting of cultivated sod, shrubs and trees, tree cutting
at or above existing ground and logging operations leaving the stump, ground
cover and root mat intact;
   (e)   For individual private septic systems which do not alter the natural
terrain;
   (f)   For excavation below finished grade for basements and pads for
additions to a single-family structure or for retaining walls, swimming pools
or accessory buildings authorized by a valid building permit, unless a
possibility for erosion and sedimentation or alteration of drainage is such as
to necessitate a grading permit as determined by the City Engineer; and
   (g)   For quarry operations and the stockpiling, with slopes at a natural
angle of repose, of raw or processed sand, stone and gravel at quarries,
concrete, asphalt and material processing plants and storage yards, provided
that sediment and erosion measures as approved by the City Engineer have been
and are being employed.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72.)
1222.06 PERMIT APPLICATION.
   To obtain a permit, an applicant shall first file an application therefor in
writing upon forms furnished by the City. Eight copies of the application and
the required plans, specifications, timing schedule and cost estimate shall be
filed with the City Engineer. The application must be signed by the owner of
the property or an authorized agent. If the owner is a corporation, it must be
signed by the president or vice-president thereof, attested by the secretary or
assistant secretary thereof and the corporate seal affixed. A separate
application shall be required for each site. No permit shall be transferable
without the written consent of the City Engineer. No permit shall be issued for
grading which is for construction or development not permitted by zoning or
subdivision regulations applicable to the land.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72. )
1222.07 DATA REQUIRED.
   (a)   The plans, specifications, timing schedule and cost estimate
accompanying the application shall, to the extent required by the City
Engineer, taking into account the magnitude and extent of the proposed
activity, be submitted to and approved by the City Engineer prior to the
commencement of any activity regulated by this chapter and shall include the
following data:
      (1)   A vicinity map drawn to a scale of not less than 2,000 feet to one
inch showing the relationship of the site to its general surroundings;
      (2)   A plan of the site drawn to a scale of not less than 100 feet to
one inch showing:
         A.   The boundary lines of the site on which the work is to be
performed, including the approximate acreage of the site;
         B.   Existing topography on the site and on land adjacent to the site
within 100 feet of the site boundary lines, including the location of any
buildings, structures, utilities, sewers, water and storm drains, wooded areas
and other significant natural features.
   The topographic map shall show one-foot contour intervals where the natural
slope does not exceed five percent; two-foot contour intervals where the
natural slope is between five and ten percent; and five-foot contour intervals
where the natural slope is in excess of ten percent. Such topography shall be
delineated for the land area within and adjacent to the plat for a minimum
distance of 100 feet. All elevation shall be based on U.S.G.S. datum plane.
         C.   Proposed improvements on the site, including present development
and future utilization, if known;
         D.   All drainage provisions, erosion and sediment control measures,
vegetative practices or other protective devices to be constructed in
connection with or as part of the proposed work;
         E.   Provisions for erosion control during construction (temporary)
and during the life of the facility (permanent). Such provisions shall include
a timing schedule and sequence of operations indicating the anticipated
starting and completion dates of the particular development sequence. Included
also shall be the estimated time of exposure of each area prior to the
completion of effective erosion and sediment control measures.
         F.   A complete and adequate grading plan for borrow pits, quarries
and material processing facilities where applicable;
         G.   A general description and location of the predominant soil types
on the site;
         H.   The name and address of the owner, developer and petitioner; and
         I.   The title, scale, north arrow, date and name of the individual or
organization preparing the plans;
      (3)   Detailed plans of all drainage provisions, retaining walls,
cribbing, vegetative practices, erosion and sediment control measures, location
of approved fences around sediment basins, steep slopes or ponding areas, and
other protective devices to be constructed in connection with or as a part of
the proposed work, together with a map showing the drainage area of land
tributary to the site and the estimated cubic foot per second runoff of the
area served by any watercourse, computed in accordance with current City storm
drainage criteria; and
      (4)   The estimated quantity and cost, including material and
installation costs, of the required erosion controls.
   (b)   The plans and specifications shall be supported by such supplemental
reports, data and additional information as the City Engineer may reasonably
require, including, but not limited to, any of the following:
      (1)   Finished contours at the same interval as required or used for
existing topography, proposed building and pavement grades and the elevations,
dimensions, locations, extent and slope of all proposed grading;
      (2)   Storm drainage computations and studies, including the estimated
run-off from the area served by any drains, ditch and pipe computations and a
map showing the drainage area of land tributary to the site;
      (3)   Field investigation reports indicating the nature, condition and
characteristics of existing drainage and flooding conditions; and
      (4)   Results from actual soil investigations, reports or test borings,
if
applicable.
   (c)   The City Engineer may waive the requirements for plans,
specifications, timing schedules or cost estimates if he or she finds that the
information on the application is sufficient to show that the work will conform
to the requirements of this chapter.
   (d)   The plans and specifications accompanying the application shall be
prepared and certified by a professional engineer or other person qualified and
approved by the City Engineer.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72. )
1222.08 DESIGN STANDARDS.
   (a)   Detailed plans and specifications for effective erosion and
sedimentation control shall be based on the practical combination of the
following principals:
      (1)   Wherever feasible, natural vegetation should be retained and
protected. (2) The development plan should be fitted to the topography and
soils so as to create the least erosion potential.
      (3)   The smallest practical area of land should be exposed at any one
time during development.
      (4)   When land is exposed during development, the exposure should be
kept to the shortest practical period of time.
      (5)   Temporary vegetation and/or mulching should be used to protect
critical areas exposed during development.
      (6)   Planned engineering works should be constructed to slow down the
velocity of run-off.
      (7)   The volume of run-off on a denuded area should be reduced with
planned diversions to protected areas.
      (8)   Provisions should be made to effectively accommodate the
concentrated and increased run-off caused by changed soil and surface
conditions during and after development.
      (9)   Sediment basins (debris basins, desilting basins or silt traps)
should be installed and maintained to remove sediment from run-off waters from
land undergoing development.
      (10)   Frequent inspection and continual maintenance of erosion and
sedimentation controls should be performed.
      (11)   The permanent final vegetation and structures should be installed
as soon as practical in the development.
   (b)   All plans and specifications shall include provisions for erosion and
sedimentation control in substantial accordance with the latest revised issue
of "Water Management and Sediment Control for Urbanizing Areas" published by
the United States Department of Agriculture, Soil Conservation Service,
Columbus, Ohio, and any other applicable standards as Council may adopt by
resolution, which are hereby incorporated in this chapter by reference.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72.)
1222.09 ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF PERMIT.
   (a)   In granting any permit, the City Engineer may attach such conditions
thereto as he or she may deem reasonably necessary to prevent danger to public
or private property or to any sewer, storm drain or watercourse, or to prevent
the operation from being conducted in a manner hazardous to life or property or
in a manner likely to create a nuisance. Such conditions may include, but are
not limited to, the erection or installation of walls, drains, dams,
structures, plantings, vegetation and erosion and sediment control measures or
devices, furnishing necessary easements and a specified method of performing
the work. No permit shall be issued until the grading, erosion and sediment
control plans, specifications, timing schedule and cost estimate are approved
by the City Engineer and until the developer certifies that all work will be
performed pursuant to the approved plans, specifications and schedules.
   (b)   If the application conforms substantially to the requirements of this
chapter, the City Engineer shall approve the same and forward one copy with a
grading permit to the applicant without unreasonable delay. If the application
does not so conform, the application shall be disapproved by the City Engineer
and his or her written disapproval, with the reasons therefor, shall be
forwarded to the applicant without unreasonable delay.
   (c)   After actual work begins, the City Engineer may require additional or
revised controls from time to time in the event the originally approved
controls prove to be inadequate.
   (d)   Permits issued pursuant to this chapter do not relieve the owner of
responsibility for securing required permits for work to be done which is
regulated by any other applicable code or ordinance.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72. )
1222.10 RESPONSIBILITIES OF PERMITTEE.
   During grading operations the permittee shall be responsible for:
   (a)   Carrying out the proposed work in accordance with the grading permit
and the approved plans, specifications and timing schedule, and in compliance
with all the requirements of this chapter;
   (b)   The prevention of damage to any public utilities or the interruption
of services within the limits of grading and along any routes of travel of
construction equipment;
   (c)   The prevention of damage to adjacent property. No person shall grade
on land so close to the property line as to endanger any adjoining public
street, sidewalk, alley or public or private property without supporting and
protecting such property from settling, cracking or other damage which might
result.
   (d)   The prompt removal of all soil, miscellaneous debris or other material
spilled, dumped or otherwise deposited on public streets, highways, sidewalks
or other public thoroughfares during transit to and from the construction site.
The construction of a haul road or other approved vehicle cleaning method may
be required by the City Engineer to prevent the spread of debris.
   (e)   The prevention of all sediment from entering into any public sewerage
system or watercourse.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72.)
1222.11 REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF PERMITS.
   Any permit issued under this chapter may be revoked or suspended by the City
Engineer, after notice, for:
   (a)   Violation of any condition of the permit;
   (b)   Violation of any provision of this chapter or any other applicable
law, ordinance, rule or regulation relating to the work; or
   (c)   Existence of any condition or the doing of any act constituting or
creating a nuisance or hazard or endangering human life or the property of
others.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72.)
1222.12 TIME EXTENSION FOR COMPLETION OF WORK.
   If the applicant is unable to complete the work within the time specified in
the permit, he or she may, prior to the expiration of such time, present in
writing a request for an extension of time, setting forth the reasons for the
requested extension. If the City Engineer finds that such an extension is
warranted, he or she may grant additional time for the completion of the work
subject to such additional measures as he or she may reasonably require.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72. )
1222.13 PLAN MODIFICATIONS.
   All modifications of the approved plans, specifications, timing schedule and
cost estimate shall be submitted to and approved by the City Engineer. Major
modifications of the approved plans shall be reprocessed in the same manner as
the original plan.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72.)
1222.14 PERFORMANCE BOND.
   The City Engineer shall, before issuing a permit, require a cash bond or
corporate bond in a form satisfactory to him or her and approved by the
Director of Law, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the conditions in
the permit and soil erosion and sediment control measures specified in the
permit within the time specified in the permit or within any extension thereof
granted by the City Engineer, in the amount of the total estimated cost of all
erosion and sediment control measures and safeguards for adjoining property.
The City Engineer may grant a waiver of such bond, upon application, where he
or she finds minimal impairment of existing surface drainage, minimal erosion
hazard and minimal sedimentation hazard upon any adjacent land or watercourse
and no hazard to human life or property.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72. )
1222.15 LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   If the City Engineer finds that the nature of the work is such that it may
create a hazard to human life, or endanger adjoining property or property at a
higher or lower elevation, or any street or street improvement, or any other
public property, then the City Engineer may, before issuing the permit, require
that the applicant for a permit file a certificate of insurance showing that he
or she is insured against claims for damages for personal injury and property
damage in an amount not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000),
including damage to the City by deposit or washing of material onto City
streets or other public improvements which may arise from or out of the
performance of the work, whether such performance is by himself or herself, his
or her subcontractor or any person directly or indirectly employed by him or
her. The amount of such insurance shall be prescribed by the City Engineer in
accordance with the nature of the risks involved. Such insurance shall be
written by a company licensed to do business in the State and approved by the
City. Neither issuance of a permit nor compliance with the provisions hereof or
any condition imposed by the City shall relieve any person from any
responsibility for damage to persons or property otherwise imposed by law nor
impose any liability upon the City for damage to persons or property.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72; Res. 19-88. Passed 4-26-88.)
1222.16 MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS.
   The permittee or the owner of any property on which work has been done
pursuant to a permit granted hereunder, or any other person or agent in control
of such property, shall maintain in good condition and promptly repair or
restore all grade surfaces, walls, drains, dams, structures, plantings,
vegetation, erosion and sediment control measures and other protective devices.
Such repair and/or restoration and maintenance shall be in accordance with the
approved plans, specifications and permit as required by this chapter until
permanent measures are accepted by the City.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72. )
1222.17 APPEALS; VARIANCES; EXCEPTIONS.
   Appeals, where it is alleged there is an error in any order, requirement,
decision or determination made by the City Engineer in the enforcement of this
chapter, and applications for variances and exceptions to any of the provisions
of this chapter, shall be taken to a special Board of Appeals appointed as
provided in Section 1222-18. Such Board, when created, shall have authority to
hear and decide appeals where it is alleged that there is an error in any
order, requirement, decision or determination made by the City Engineer in the
enforcement of this chapter. Such Board shall also have authority to interpret
this chapter and may, upon application and a showing of undue hardship, grant
variances and exceptions to any of the provisions of this chapter, provided
that such variances and exceptions are in harmony with the general purpose and
intent of this chapter. Variances and exceptions granted shall apply only to
applications decided by the Board of Appeals.
   Any person claiming to be aggrieved by any order, requirement, decision or
determination made by the City Engineer may file an appeal with the City
Manager who shall create a Board of Appeals as provided in Section
1222.18. Such appeal shall be taken within twenty days of the date of the
decision by filing with the City Manager a notice of appeal specifying the
grounds thereof. The City Engineer shall transmit to the Board all of the
papers constituting the record of the action upon which the appeal is taken.
The Board's decision in such appeals shall be limited to alleged errors in the
interpretation of this chapter.
   Any permittee may file an application with the City Manager for the creation
of an appeals board to consider variances and exceptions from this chapter, and
the City Manager shall, in such cases, create a Board of Appeals as provided in
Section
1222.18. Such application shall be made as soon as practical after the undue
hardship from which relief is sought becomes apparent. Each application shall
refer to the specific provisions of this chapter involved and set forth exactly
a clear description of the land involved, the interpretation that is claimed,
the details of the variance to be granted or the reasons justifying the
exception.
   Orders, requirements, decisions and determinations made by the City Engineer
shall remain in effect until and unless reversed or modified by the Board of
Appeals.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72.)
1222.18 BOARD OF APPEALS.
   Whenever a complete appeal or application provided for in Section
1222.17 is made to the City Manager, he or she shall promptly, and not later
than twenty days after receipt of such appeal or application, cause the
creation of a Board of Appeals to hear and decide the matter. The Board shall
be composed of three members who shall be residents of the County, not in the
employ of the City or the appellant/applicant. One member shall be appointed by
the City Manager and shall be the Chairman of the Board; one member shall be
appointed by the appellant/applicant; and the third member, who shall be
qualified by experience or training in erosion and sedimentation control, shall
be appointed jointly by the City Manager and the appellant/applicant. The City
Manager shall provide a recording secretary. Decisions of the Board of Appeals
shall be by a majority and shall be recorded, signed by the members and filed
with the City records. The Board shall establish its own rules and procedures
governing the conduct of its business. Members of the Board shall serve until a
decision is rendered in the case which caused its creation. Decisions shall be
rendered within thirty days from creation of the Board. Members of the Board
shall be allowed a fee paid by the City of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for
each case heard and decided.
   Appeals from decisions of the Board shall be to the County Court of Common
Pleas.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72.)
1222.19 FEES FOR APPEALS, VARIANCES AND EXCEPTIONS.
   Every person filing a notice of appeal as provided in this chapter shall
deposit the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) with the Director of Finance
at the time such notice is given. If the Board decides the appeal in favor of
the appellant, the Director shall return the deposit to the appellant and no
fee shall be charged for the appeal. If, however, the Board's decision is to
uphold the order, requirement, decision or determination of the City Engineer,
the Director shall pay into the Treasury the aforementioned deposit as the fee
for filing the notice of appeal by the appellant.
   Every person filing an application for a variance or exception shall pay to
the City a fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00).
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72.)
1222.20 PERMIT FEES.
   Fees for permits required by this chapter shall be determined by resolution
of Council.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72. )
1222.21 INSPECTION AND ENFORCEMENT.
   The Building Official or his or her authorized representative shall inspect
the work done under the approved plans, specifications, timing schedule and
permit from time to time as he or she may deem advisable.
   Whenever the Building Official finds that work under any permit fails to
conform to the approved plans, specifications and timing schedule, he or she
may, as he or she deems reasonably necessary, by written order direct
conformity, direct suspension of other work until conformity has been achieved
or direct such other measures that he or she deems reasonably necessary under
the circumstances for control of erosion and sedimentation on the site.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72; Ord. 05-6. Passed 3-8-05.)
1222.22 LIABILITY.
   Neither the issuance of permits under the provisions of this chapter, nor
the compliance with the provisions of this chapter or with any conditions
imposed by the City Engineer hereunder, shall relieve any person from the
responsibility for damage to any person or property otherwise imposed by law,
or impose any liability upon the City for damage to any person or property.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72. )
1222.23 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, unless otherwise expressly provided or the context
otherwise requires:
   (a)   "Building" means any structure having a roof supported by columns or
walls for the housing or enclosure of persons, animals or chattels. When any
portion thereof is completely separated from every other portion thereof by a
division wall without openings, then each such portion shall be deemed to be a
separate building.
   (b)   "Building permit" means a permit issued by the Code Enforcement
Officer of the City stating that the proposed erection, construction,
enlargement or moving of a building or structure referred to therein complies
with the provisions of the Zoning Code of the City.
   (c)   "City Engineer" means the officer designated and authorized by the
City Manager to carry out various functions as specified in this chapter.
   (d)   "Clearing" means the clearing, grubbing, scalping, removal of trees
and stumps and removal and disposal of all vegetation and debris within the
site, and includes the conditions resulting therefrom.
   (e)   "Construction" means the erection, alteration, repair, renovation,
demolition or removal of any building or structure and the clearing, stripping,
excavating, filling, grading and regulating of sites in connection therewith.
   (f)   "Debris" means loose refuse or earth material not suitable for use as
presently situated or constituted, as determined by the City Engineer.
   (g)   "Developer" means any individual, subdivider, firm, association,
syndicate, partnership, corporation, trust or other legal entity commencing
proceedings under this chapter to effect the development of land for himself or
herself or for another.
   (h)   "Filling" means to deposit, place, push, pull or transport soil,
earth, sand, gravel, rock or any similar material by any act, and includes the
conditions resulting therefrom.
   (i)   "Finished grade" means the final grade or elevation of the ground
surface conforming to the approved grading plan.
   (j)   "Grading permit" means a permit issued by the City Engineer to
authorize work to be performed in compliance with this chapter.
   (k)   "Hazard" means any danger to public health, welfare and safety,
including exposure to risk of damage to property or liability for personal
injury, or risk of harm to land, air or water resulting in environmental
degradation. Hazards can include flooding and ponding, compaction and settling,
landslides, earthquakes, toxic chemicals, radiation, fire and disease.
   (1)   "Nuisance" means a public nuisance as known at common law or in equity
jurisprudence.
   (m)   "Permittee" means any person to whom a permit is issued pursuant to
this chapter, or who is subject to inspection under this chapter.
   (n)   "Plans" means the profiles, typical cross-sections, working drawings
and supplemental drawings, site, grading, drainage and erosion and
sedimentation control plans, the vicinity map, the soil map and other plans as
approved by the City Engineer, or exact reproductions thereof, which show the
location, character, dimensions and details of the work.
   (o)   "Professional engineer" means a professional engineer, duly registered
or otherwise authorized by the State, whose specialty is the field of civil
engineering.
   (p)   "Site" means any lot or parcel of land or a series of lots or parcels
of land adjoining or contiguous or joined together under one ownership where
clearing, stripping, grading, excavating or filling is performed.
   (q)   "Soil" means all earth material of whatever origin that overlies
bedrock and may include the decomposed zone of bedrock which can be readily
excavated by mechanical equipment.
   (r)   "Specifications" means all the directions, provisions and
requirements, together with such as may be added or adopted as supplemental
specifications or special provisions approved by the City Engineer.
   (s)   "Steep slope" means a slope over fifteen percent grade, which is
characterized by increased runoff, erosion and sediment hazards.
   (t)   "Stripping" means any activity which removes or significantly disturbs
the vegetative surface cover.
   (u)   "Timing schedule" means a construction progress schedule showing the
proposed dates of commencement and completion of each of the various
subdivisions of work as shown and called for in the approved plans and
specifications.
   (v)   "Variance" means a modification of the strict terms of this chapter
where such modification will not be contrary to the public interest and where,
owing to conditions peculiar to the property and not the result of the action
of the applicant, a literal enforcement of the regulations would result in
unnecessary and undue hardship.
   (w)   "Watercourse" means any natural or artificial watercourse, including,
but not limited to, streams, rivers, creeks, ditches, channels, canals,
conduits, culverts, drains, drainageways, waterways, gullies, ravines and
washes, in which waters flow in a definite direction or course, either
continuously or intermittently, and including any area adjacent thereto which
is subject to inundation by reason of overflow or flood water.
(Ord. 72-41. Passed 12-12-72. )
1222.99 PENALTY; EQUITABLE REMEDIES.
   Any owner or other person in possession of land who violates or fails to
comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not more than one thousand
dollars ($1, 000) or imprisoned not more than six months, or both, for each
offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues. In addition, the City
may institute injunction, mandamus or any other appropriate action or
proceeding at law or in equity for the enforcement of this chapter or to
correct violations of this chapter, and any court of competent jurisdiction
shall have the right to issue restraining orders, temporary or permanent
injunctions or mandamus or other appropriate forms of remedy or relief.

Landscaping

1266.03(d)
1224.01 FINDINGS.
   Council hereby finds that changes in land use and zoning classification
resulting from the sprawl of urbanization has often necessitated the removal of
trees and other valuable natural resources and often has the effect of
degrading the appearance, character and value of existing land use patterns
within and surrounding the City.
(Ord. 78-27. Passed 4-25-78. )
1224.02 PURPOSES.
   The purposes of this chapter are to protect and promote the public health,
safety and general welfare by fully utilizing the benefits of landscaping in
new developments to ensure that the local stock of native trees is replenished;
to contribute to the process of air purification, oxygen regeneration, ground
water recharge and storm water run-off retardation, while at the same time
aiding in noise, glare and heat abatement; to buffer uncomplimentary and often
incompatible land uses by providing a transitional interface; to assist in
controlling traffic to and from, as well as within, off-street parking
facilities by limiting the internal movement of vehicles and pedestrians to
designated traffic configurations; to relieve the blighted appearance of
parking lots; and to otherwise facilitate the creation of a convenient,
attractive and harmonious community and preserve a healthful and pleasant
environment.
(Ord. 78-27. Passed 4-25-78. )
1224.03 INTENT; APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   The intent of this chapter is to:
   (a)   Encourage landscape development in publicly and privately developed
land use areas, except agricultural and one and two-family residential zones;
   (b)   Foster a community-wide reforestation program;
   (c)   Require the installation and maintenance of landscape planting areas
in off-street parking facilities and other vehicular use areas; and
   (d)   Require the installation and maintenance of landscape buffer areas
between uncomplimentary land uses and zones as herein set forth.
   All new development, construction or reconstruction shall be in compliance
with the provisions of this chapter within one calendar year from the date of
completion of construction. Where a building permit has been issued prior to
the effective date of this chapter, the provisions of this chapter shall not
apply.
(Ord. 78-27. Passed 4-25-78. )
1224.04 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Architectural planter" means a container within which plantings may
be placed to meet the requirements of this chapter.
   (b)   "Crown spread" means the distance measured across the greatest
diameter of a plant.
   (c)   "Decorative walls and fences" means barriers constructed of wood,
masonry or other appropriate material.
   (d)   "Developed area" means that portion of a plot or parcel of land upon
which a building, structure, pavement, landscape material or other improvement,
excluding public rights of way, has been placed.
   (e)   "Drip line" means the outer perimeter of the crown of a plant.
   (f)   "Encroachment" means any protrusion of a vehicle outside of a parking
space, display area, storage area, accessway or access aisle into a landscaped
area.
   (g)   "Ground cover" means natural mulch or low growing plants other than
deciduous varieties installed in such a manner so as to form a continuous cover
over the ground.
   (h)   "Landscape" means the placement of landscape material in the planting
area in accordance with the requirements of this chapter.
   (i)   "Landscape material" means landscaping consisting of material such as,
but not limited to, living trees; shrubs; vines; lawn grass; ground cover;
landscape water features; and nonliving durable material commonly used in
landscaping, including, but not limited to, rocks, pebbles, sand, decorative
walls and fences, brick pavers and earthen mounds, but excluding pavements for
vehicular use.
   (j)   "Planting area" means any area designed for landscape material
installation having a minimum area of sixty-four square feet.
   (k)   "Shrub" means a woody perennial plant differing from a perennial herb
by its persistent and woody stems and from a tree by its low stature and habit
of branching from the base.
   (l)   "Tree" means any self-supporting, woody plant of a species which
normally grows to an overall height of at least fifteen feet and normally
develops an average mature crown spread greater than fifteen feet in
southwestern Ohio.
   (m)   "Tree standard" means, unless otherwise provided, a tree planted to
the dimensions of at least a two-inch caliber and fifteen feet in height.
   (n)   "Vehicular use area" means any paved ground surface area, except
public rights of way, used by any type of vehicle, whether moving or at rest,
for the following purposes, among other possible purposes: driving, parking,
loading, unloading, storage or display. Such areas include, but are not limited
to, new and used car lots, activities of a drive-in nature in connection with
banks, restaurants, filling stations and grocery and dairy stores and other
open lot uses, except areas used for parking or other vehicular uses under, on
or within buildings.
   (o)   "Visual screen" means a barrier, at least eighty percent opaque, of
living or nonliving landscape material put in place for the purpose of
separating and obscuring from view those areas so screened.
   (p)   "Reconstruction" means rehabilitation or replacement of a structure on
property which either has been damaged, altered or removed to an extent
exceeding sixty percent of the assessed valuation of such structure as shown on
the most recent tax roll of the County.
(Ord. 78-27. Passed 4-25-78.)
1224.05 LANDSCAPE PLAN REQUIRED.
   No vehicular use area of 10,000 square feet or more shall be constructed,
enlarged or reconstructed in the City until a landscape plan has been approved
by the City Engineer. The Engineer shall not approve any landscape plan
submitted to him or her pursuant to this section unless it conforms to the
requirements of this chapter. Landscape plans submitted pursuant to this
chapter shall be prepared by a landscape architect and may, where appropriate,
be submitted as part of the site plan submittals required for a building permit
pursuant to the Zoning Code. Landscape plans submitted pursuant to this chapter
shall be drawn to scale, including dimensions and distances, and clearly
delineate the existing and proposed parking spaces or other vehicular use
areas, access aisles, driveways and the location, size and description of all
landscape materials.
(Ord. 78-27. Passed 4-25-78. )
1224.06 STANDARDS FOR OFF-STREET PARKING FACILITIES.
   Public and private off-street parking facilities and other vehicular use
areas shall be landscaped in accordance with the following requirements.
   (a)   Perimeter Requirements. The set-back area for off-street parking
facilities and other vehicular use areas as provided in the Zoning Code shall
be devoted to perimeter landscape. However, a ten-foot wide strip of land
located between the front property line and the vehicular use area shall be
landscaped. In addition to the requirements of the Zoning Code, one tree
conforming to the tree standard shall be planted within the front set-back area
for each thirty-five feet of lot frontage.
(Ord. 78-27. Passed 4-25-78.)
   (b)   Interior Off-Street Parking Requirements.
      (1)   Within parking areas for ten or more vehicles, four percent of the
paved parking area shall be reserved for interior landscaping if the site is
less than five acres in size, and five percent of the paved area shall be
reserved if the site is five acres or larger.
      (2)   Interior landscaping areas shall be at least forty square feet in
area.
      (3)   Parking lots for more than fifty automobiles shall have interior
landscaping areas completely surrounded by functional paved parking.
      (4)   Parking lots for fewer than fifty automobiles may have interior
landscaping areas surrounded on three sides by functional paved parking.
      (5)   Interior landscape areas shall be raised or curbed.
      (6)   Each 200 square feet of required interior landscaping area shall
require one tree conforming to the tree standard specified in Section
1224.04(m).
      (7)   Up to one percent of required interior landscaping area may be
relocated elsewhere to emphasize an entrance corridor or feature, if approved b
the City Manager or his or her designee.
      (8)   Landscaped areas interior to parking lots shall be designed and
arranged so as to divide parking corridors and limit vehicular movements
outside designated aisles.
      (9)   Traffic hazards shall be minimized where parking lot ingress/egress
drives interact with public rights-of-way trough application of the same
visibility standards as are contained in Section
1266.03(c)(1) of the Zoning Code. Landscaping exceeding a height of eight
inches shall not be utilized closer than three feet from the edge of a public
right-of-way pavement.
      (10)   Grass, living vegetative matter or other organic and commonly used
landscape material shall be planted on all portions of interior landscape areas
not otherwise occupied.
      (11)   The minimum width of a landscaped area shall be four feet, except
that the minimum distance from a tree to a vehicular use area shall be four
feet as measured from the face of the tree. Vehicles may overhang a landscaped
area not more than two feet when parked heading to a landscaped area in a
marked parking space. The overhang distance may be counted as part of the
required depth of each parking space.
(Ord. 92-26. Passed 7-14-92.)
   (c)   Distribution Variances. In vehicular use areas where the City Engineer
has determined that the strict application of this section will interfere with
the function of the area, the required interior landscaping may be located near
the perimeter of the paved area, including such perimeters which may be
adjacent to a building.
(Ord. 78-27. Passed 4-25-78.)
1224.07 LANDSCAPE BUFFER RELATING TO UNCOMPLIMENTARY LAND USES AND ZONES.
   The requirements of Section
1266.03 (d) of the Zoning Code shall apply, but, in addition, any industrial
use or zone, when adjacent to an "R," "S-PUD" or "0-1" District shall be
screened.
(Ord. 78-27. Passed 4-25-78.)
1224.08 REFORESTATION PROGRAM REQUIREMENT.
   (a)   The number of trees meeting the tree standard required on any
developed zoning lot, other than those zoned "R," "O," "I" or "S-PUD," shall be
as least one tree per one-tenth acre, rounded to the nearest one-tenth acre,
plus and including the trees called for in subsection (b) hereof.
   (b)   The number of trees meeting the tree standard required within the
front yard of any developed zoning lot zoned "R," "O," "I" or "S-PUD," shall be
at least the greater of two trees per zoning lot or one tree per forty feet of
lot frontage, calculated by dividing lot frontage by forty and rounding to the
nearest whole number.
   (c)   In addition to required trees, every zoning lot on which is hereafter
erected a principal structure shall, before occupancy, have its front yard
planted with at least eight shrubs. If said lot is a corner lot, the number of
front yard shrubs shall equal at least ten. Additionally, the entirety of front
and side yards shall be sodded with grass, and twenty feet of the rear yard
closest to the principal structure shall be sodded.
(Ord. 92-37. Passed 11-24-92.)
1224.09 CREDIT FOR PRESERVING EXISTING TREES.
   Credit may be received on the reforestation requirement by preserving
existing trees, except for the perimeter tree planting requirements as provided
in Sections
1224.05 and 1224. 06, unless the location of the preserved tree is within the
perimeter area.
   (a)   Exchange Rate. The reforestation requirement shall be credited for
preserved trees at the following rate*:

   (b)   *Crown spread measurement shall be rounded off to the nearest whole
